question_text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized malaise, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and pruritus on the back of his hands that worsens when exposed to sunlight for the past several months. He has not seen a physician in 15 years. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild jaundice. There is a pruritic rash with several small vesicles and hyperpigmented lesions on the dorsum of both hands. The causal pathogen of this patient's underlying condition was most likely acquired in which of the following ways?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized malaise, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and pruritus on the back of his hands that worsens when exposed to sunlight for the past several months. He has not seen a physician in 15 years. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild jaundice. There is a pruritic rash with several small vesicles and hyperpigmented lesions on the dorsum of both hands. The causal pathogen of this patient's underlying condition was most likely acquired in which of the following ways?
hint: This patient's scleral icterus and jaundice should raise suspicion for liver disease. His pruritic rash that worsens upon exposure to sunlight is suggestive of porphyria cutanea tarda, a condition that is associated with hepatitis C virus infection.
learning_objective: Recognize porphyria cutanea tarda, and recall the transmission of hepatitis C virus.

answers.content: Bathing in freshwater
answers.explanation_why: Bathing in freshwater is a risk factor for schistosomiasis, a helminthic infection that can manifest with various different clinical manifestations depending on the exact species involved. Hepatosplenic schistosomiasis could also cause signs of liver damage but it is not associated with porphyria cutanea tarda, as seen in this patient.

answers.content: Ingestion of raw shellfish
answers.explanation_why: Ingestion of raw shellfish is one of the major transmission modes for hepatitis A, which is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. Shellfish can concentrate the virus from seawater contaminated with human sewage, especially in regions with poor sanitation. Hepatitis C, which this patient most likely has, is not transmitted via food.

answers.content: Needlestick injury
answers.explanation_why: Needlestick injury is a likely cause of this patient's hepatitis C infection as it is mainly transmitted parenterally. Therefore, certain populations such as health care workers and IV drug users are at increased risk of contracting the virus. Patients who received blood transfusions before 1992 are also at increased risk for hepatitis C, as donor blood was not screened for the virus before 1992. Other routes of transmission include vertical (from mother to fetus) and, rarely, sexual.

answers.content: Inhalation of spores
answers.explanation_why: The inhalation of spores is the mode of transmission for several different infections, including mucormycosis, Q fever, and pulmonary anthrax. Spore inhalation is not the mechanism of transmission for hepatitis C, which this patient has.

answers.content: Sexual contact
answers.explanation_why: Sexual contact is the route of transmission for many infectious diseases, including syphilis, hepatitis B, and HIV. Hepatitis C may be transmitted sexually (especially in cases of HIV coinfection), however, this is very rare and another route of transmission is more likely.

question_text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of lower back pain. He has had several episodes of painless hematuria over the past 2 months. Physical examination shows localized tenderness over the lumbar spine. A CT scan shows multiple osteolytic lesions in the body of the lumbar vertebrae. Cystoscopy shows a 4-cm mass in the right lateral wall of the bladder. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of lower back pain. He has had several episodes of painless hematuria over the past 2 months. Physical examination shows localized tenderness over the lumbar spine. A CT scan shows multiple osteolytic lesions in the body of the lumbar vertebrae. Cystoscopy shows a 4-cm mass in the right lateral wall of the bladder. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
hint: The photomicrograph shows a fibrovascular core surrounded by a thickened, dysplastic urothelium with loss of polarity. These features are consistent with transitional cell urothelial carcinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize transitional cell urothelial carcinoma, and recall its primary risk factor.

answers.content: Alcohol consumption
answers.explanation_why: Chronic alcohol consumption is associated with an increased risk of hepatic and esophageal carcinomas as well as chronic pancreatitis, which may increase the risk of pancreatic carcinomas. Although chronic pancreatitis may also manifest with chronic back pain, this patient's back complaints and CT findings are more consistent with metastatic lesions. Alcohol consumption is not known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma.

answers.content: Cigarette smoking
answers.explanation_why:
Smoking is the most important risk factor for the development of both the transitional cell type of carcinomas of the bladder and the less common squamous cell type. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include long-term occupational exposure to benzidine and aniline dyes as well as previous cyclophosphamide treatment. Most urothelial cancers occur in males > 65 years, and affected individuals classically present with painless gross hematuria. This patient's osteolytic lesions and lower back pain indicate advanced metastatic disease.

When in doubt, the most commonly tested risk factor on exam questions is cigarette smoking, and smoking cessation is the best way to improve overall health!

answers.content: Clonorchis infection
answers.explanation_why: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis, or Chinese liver fluke, is a significant risk factor for development of cholangiocarcinoma. Patients with cholangiocarcinomas typically present with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, and pale stools, unlike this patient with primarily urinary complaints. Clonorchis infection does not increase the risk for bladder carcinoma.

answers.content: Schistosoma infection
answers.explanation_why: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder is the most common type of bladder cancer in regions with a high prevalence of Schistosoma haematobium infection, such as the Middle East and Sub-Saharan Africa. Biopsy of a squamous cell carcinoma would classically show epithelial infiltrates, keratin pearls, and intercellular bridges. While this patient presents with painless hematuria and a bladder mass on cystoscopy, his biopsy findings demonstrate features consistent with transitional cell carcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma. Additional risk factors for development of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder include chronic cystitis.

answers.content: Vinyl chloride exposure
answers.explanation_why: Long-term exposure to vinyl chloride is associated with an increased risk of hepatic angiosarcoma, lymphoma, glioblastoma, and lung carcinoma. However, there is no known association between vinyl chloride exposure and risk of developing bladder cancer.

answers.content: Nitrosamine ingestion
answers.explanation_why: Nitrosamine is a chemical most commonly found in cured, smoked, and processed foods. High consumption of this substance has been associated with an increased risk of gastric carcinoma, but not with a higher risk of bladder cancer.

images.title: Papillary urothelial carcinoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a bladder tumor biopsy specimen (H&E stain)A thick papilla with a fibrovascular core (red overlay) can be seen in the center.
The urothelium (green overlay) appears hyperplastic and the normal stratification of the urothelial cells is absent.
The nuclei of the urothelial cells are large and deeply staining (nuclear atypia).
The basal cells of the urothelium are not in contact with the basement membrane (loss of polarity).These features are characteristic of papillary urothelial carcinoma.

question_text: A 21-year-old man comes to the military base physician for evaluation of progressive discomfort in his right shoulder for the past 4 months. He joined the military 6 months ago and is part of a combat team. In anticipation of an upcoming competition, he has been practicing rifle drills and firing exercises 8 hours a day. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation and a firm mass in the superior part of the right deltopectoral groove. Range of motion is limited by pain and stiffness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 21-year-old man comes to the military base physician for evaluation of progressive discomfort in his right shoulder for the past 4 months. He joined the military 6 months ago and is part of a combat team. In anticipation of an upcoming competition, he has been practicing rifle drills and firing exercises 8 hours a day. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation and a firm mass in the superior part of the right deltopectoral groove. Range of motion is limited by pain and stiffness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's presentation indicates a condition involving metaplasia of the connective tissue.
learning_objective: Recognize myositis ossificans.

answers.content: Osteoid osteoma
answers.explanation_why: Osteoid osteomas typically affect boys and young men (10–30 years of age) and can cause chronic pain. However, osteoid osteomas are not associated with muscle overuse or repetitive trauma. Moreover, osteoid osteomas occur in the cortex of the diaphysis of long bones and would not explain this patient's palpable mass in the deltopectoral groove.

answers.content: Lipoma
answers.explanation_why: Lipomas may present as a palpable mass of the deltopectoral groove, which is seen in this patient. However, these benign tumors are typically soft and nontender, not firm and tender to palpation like the one seen here. Moreover, lipomas are not related to muscle overuse and repetitive trauma, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient, and they would not explain this patient's limited range of motion.

images.title: Lipoma
images.description: There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).

answers.content: Acromioclavicular joint separation
answers.explanation_why: An acromioclavicular (AC) joint separation is typically caused by direct force to the point of the shoulder (e.g., a direct fall). Clinical features include shoulder pain, tenderness over the AC joint, and limited range of motion, all of which are seen here. However, AC joint separation typically occurs acutely (i.e., immediately after trauma) rather than over the course of several months. Moreover, physical examination can show a palpable elevation of the clavicle, but this elevation would not explain the palpable mass in the deltopectoral groove.

answers.content: Clavicle stress fracture
answers.explanation_why: Clavicle stress fractures may occur because of overuse and repetitive trauma of the shoulder, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient. Clinical features include shoulder pain, tenderness to palpation, and limited range of motion. Clavicle fracture would not, however, explain this patient's mass in the deltopectoral groove. Instead, sagging and shortening of the shoulder as well as tenting of the skin over the fracture site would be seen.

images.title: Clavicle fracture
images.description:
The junction of the medial second third and the lateral first third is the most common site of clavicle fractures, as depicted here. Distracting forces cause a downward dislocation of the lateral fracture fragment and an upward dislocation of the medial fracture fragment, resulting in the following clinical features:- Sagging of the ipsilateral shoulder due to downward distracting force of the weight of the upper limb on the lateral fracture fragment
- Shortening of the ipsilateral shoulder due to the medial distracting force of the pectoralis major on the lateral fracture fragment
- Tenting of the skin over the fracture site due to the upward distracting force of the sternocleidomastoid on the medial fracture fragment

answers.content: Myositis ossificans
answers.explanation_why: Myositis ossificans is caused by heterotopic ossification of the muscle and soft tissue. This condition can be genetic but typically occurs as a result of muscle overuse, trauma, neurologic conditions, or chronic degenerative diseases. This patient's history of performing rifle drills and firing exercises likely resulted in repetitive trauma to the deltopectoral groove (due to recoil from the rifle), predisposing him to myositis ossificans. Clinical features include chronic pain, stiffness, restricted range of motion, and possibly palpable masses on physical examination, all of which are seen here.

images.title: Myositis ossificans
images.description: X-ray of the left knee; AP view. Overlay shows calcification of soft tissue in the area of the distal part of the vastus medialis muscle (heterotopic ossification) as a result of myositis ossificans. (Fe = femur, T = tibia, F = fibula)

answers.content: Arteriovenous fistula
answers.explanation_why: Arteriovenous (AV) fistulas can occur after repetitive trauma, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient. However, AV fistulas are typically soft and compressible, unlike the firm and tender mass seen here. Moreover, AV fistulas are not typically located in the deltopectoral groove and would not explain this patient's limited range of motion. The most common AV fistulas in the arm are iatrogenic fistulas serving as access points for hemodialysis.

question_text:
A previously healthy 21-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of headaches and nausea for 2 months. His headaches are holocephalic and most severe upon waking up. During this time, he has also been feeling tired and sleepy during the day despite going to bed at 10 pm and sleeping for 8 hours at night. He is concerned about losing his spot on next season's college track team because of a recent decline in his performance during winter training. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 months ago, for which he did not seek medical care. One year ago he moved into a new house with his friends, where he lives in the basement. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (140 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
19.6 g/dL

Hematocrit
59.8%

Leukocyte count
9,000/mm^3

Platelet count
380,000/mm^3

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A previously healthy 21-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of headaches and nausea for 2 months. His headaches are holocephalic and most severe upon waking up. During this time, he has also been feeling tired and sleepy during the day despite going to bed at 10 pm and sleeping for 8 hours at night. He is concerned about losing his spot on next season's college track team because of a recent decline in his performance during winter training. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 months ago, for which he did not seek medical care. One year ago he moved into a new house with his friends, where he lives in the basement. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (140 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 19.6 g/dL Hematocrit 59.8% Leukocyte count 9,000/mm3 Platelet count 380,000/mm3 Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: It is probably cold in the basement during the winter.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic cerebral hypoxia due to carbon monoxide poisoning.

answers.content: Chronic cerebral hypoxia
answers.explanation_why:
Chronic cerebral hypoxia caused by chronic carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is the most likely cause of headache, somnolence, and fatigue in this patient. CO often rises to unsafe levels in confined areas with poor ventilation (e.g., basements), especially during winter months when furnaces are used for heating. CO binds to hemoglobin with an affinity ∼ 240 times stronger than that of oxygen and prevents normal oxygen delivery to cells, leading to a chronic hypoxic state. Chronic hypoxemia stimulates erythropoietin production, which causes erythrocytosis, leading to increased levels of hemoglobin and hematocrit. Patients with CO poisoning often have a normal SpO_2  because pulse oximeters cannot distinguish between carboxyhemoglobin and normal oxyhemoglobin.

In patients who are obese or hypertensive, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a differential diagnosis. OSA also causes chronic cerebral hypoxia and can manifest with morning headaches, daytime somnolence, and polycythemia.

answers.content: Increased intracranial pressure
answers.explanation_why: An increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) may cause nausea and headaches that are significantly worse in the morning. However, patients with raised ICP typically have additional symptoms, such as tinnitus and blurred vision. Also, an increase in ICP does not explain polycythemia.

answers.content: Exogenous erythropoietin use
answers.explanation_why: Some athletes use exogenous erythropoietin (EPO) to increase tissue oxygenation and enhance performance, often illegally (i.e., blood doping). Exogenous EPO use in a healthy individual can cause headaches and polycythemia. However, daytime somnolence with an increase in the severity of headache after a night's sleep and the onset of symptoms during winter make a different cause more likely.

answers.content: Acquired gene mutation
answers.explanation_why: A de novo JAK2 kinase mutation is responsible for polycythemia vera (PV), a myeloproliferative neoplasm that can lead to erythrocytosis and symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome (e.g., headache). However, patients with PV also typically have leukocytosis and thrombocytosis as PV affects the entire myeloid cell line (including granulocytes, monocytes, and platelets). In addition, PV is more common in middle-aged and older individuals, and most patients with PV will have at least one of the following clinical features: splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, or aquagenic pruritus.

answers.content: Overuse of NSAIDs
answers.explanation_why: An overuse of NSAIDs such as ibuprofen can cause nausea and medication overuse headache, which is typically worse in the morning. However, the presence of polycythemia and daytime somnolence indicate a different cause.

question_text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for a preplacement examination and tuberculosis test before volunteering at a public library. He has had a mild cough, sore throat, and occasional headaches for 1 week. He has hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He works as a mechanic and has never traveled outside of the US. He lives alone and has had no known contact with anyone infected with tuberculosis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years and does not drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and esomeprazole. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 6200/mm^3 and a hemoglobin concentration of 13.8 g/dL. A rapid test for COVID-19 is negative. A tuberculin skin test results in an induration of 13 mm in diameter after 50 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for a preplacement examination and tuberculosis test before volunteering at a public library. He has had a mild cough, sore throat, and occasional headaches for 1 week. He has hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He works as a mechanic and has never traveled outside of the US. He lives alone and has had no known contact with anyone infected with tuberculosis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years and does not drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and esomeprazole. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 6200/mm3 and a hemoglobin concentration of 13.8 g/dL. A rapid test for COVID-19 is negative. A tuberculin skin test results in an induration of 13 mm in diameter after 50 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has no risk factors for tuberculosis (TB) such as homelessness, close contact with a patient with active tuberculosis, or migration from a country with a high burden of TB.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a patient with a negative tuberculin skin test and no risk factors for tuberculosis.

answers.content: Chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why:
A chest x-ray is used along with another screening test, tuberculin skin test (TST) or IFN-γ release assay, in the initial workup of latent TB infection in certain patients who have a high risk of false negative results on the latter test (individuals with HIV, children aged < 5 years, and/or immunocompromised patients). In all other patients, a chest x-ray is only performed if the skin test is positive in order to rule out active TB. This patient has a negative TST, so a chest x-ray is not indicated.

A chest x-ray may also be performed as part of the initial diagnostic workup in patients with respiratory symptoms (productive cough, dyspnea) and/or systemic symptoms in order to narrow down the differential diagnoses (e.g., active TB). This patient only has mild respiratory symptoms that do not warrant a chest x-ray at this point.

answers.content: No further management is indicated
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with no risk factors, a tuberculin skin test (TST) is positive if the induration is ≥ 15 mm. Negative TST indicates that the patient has not been infected with TB or has been infected recently, and not enough time has elapsed for the body to react to the skin test. This patient has no signs or symptoms that suggest active or latent infection, so no further management is indicated at this time. The threshold for a positive TST depends on the patient's individual risk factors. (See “Positive TST according to induration diameter” table.)

Note that routine screening for latent TB infection (LTBI) has been replaced by a targeted screening strategy that mainly includes patients at high risk of infection or disease progression. However, there are some exceptions, such as baseline TB assessment of health care workers and volunteers. LTBI testing is typically not recommended for individuals with low risk of exposure; exceptions include local regulations that mandate broader testing policies.

answers.content: Interferon-γ release assay
answers.explanation_why: Interferon-γ release assay (IGRA), a screening test for TB infection, may be performed as an initial test or as a follow-up test (dual testing strategy) if the initial tuberculin skin test is negative but there is high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis infection (e.g., exposure to an individual with active pulmonary TB) or high risk for infection, disease progression, or a negative outcome of infection (e.g., immunocompromised patients). This patient has no risk factors for infection with or exposure to M. tuberculosis (e.g., travel to a high-prevalence country, residence in a high-risk setting), and shows no clinical features of TB (e.g., weight loss, chronic cough).

answers.content: Repeat tuberculin skin test after 8–10 weeks
answers.explanation_why: A repeat test is recommended as part of a postexposure workup for contacts of individuals with active pulmonary TB. Patients with a negative initial tuberculin skin test should be tested again 8–10 weeks after the last exposure (either with TST or interferon-γ release assay). This patient has no history indicating exposure to active TB.

answers.content: Isoniazid and rifapentine therapy
answers.explanation_why: Isoniazid and rifapentine for 3 months (3HP, short regimen) is one of the preferred treatment regimens for patients who have been diagnosed with latent TB infection (LTBI). A diagnosis of LTBI is confirmed if a patient's screening test is positive, but there is no clinical or radiographic evidence of active TB. This patient has a negative tuberculin skin test, so therapy is not indicated.

question_text:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:

Erythrocyte count
0,000001 million/mm^3

Leukocyte count
4000/mm^3

Glucose
59 mg/dL

Lactate dehydrogenase
248 U/L

Protein
3.8 g/dL

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
content_preview: A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows: Erythrocyte count 0,000001 million/mm3 Leukocyte count 4000/mm3 Glucose 59 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L Protein 3.8 g/dL Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
hint: This patient presents with chronic fatigue, nonproductive cough, weight loss, and nodular pleural lesions on x-ray, the combination of which raises concern for malignancy. Her work as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years is a risk factor for asbestos exposure. Based on Light's criteria (effusion protein: serum protein ratio > 0.5 and effusion LDH: serum LDH ratio > 0.6), this patient has an exudative pleural effusion.
learning_objective: Recognize mesothelioma as a cause of exudative pleural effusion.

answers.content: Bronchial adenocarcinoma
answers.explanation_why: Bronchial adenocarcinoma could manifest with an exudative malignant pleural effusion, and smoking and asbestos exposure both increase the risk of lung cancer. However, the x-ray shows pleural lesions rather than a parenchymal lung lesion, making the diagnosis of lung cancer less likely.

images.title: Spiculated lung mass
images.description: X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinomaA spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

answers.content: Mesothelioma
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's x-ray findings (nodular pleural lesions) and history of asbestos exposure suggest mesothelioma, a neoplastic process of the mesothelium that can manifest with malignant pleural effusion. Malignant effusion is caused by cancer-related barrier dysfunction of the capillary walls, which leads to increased permeation of plasma protein, blood cells, and tumor cells. These effusions are usually exudative and cell-rich, with a cloudy or straw-like appearance, abnormal cytology, a glucose concentration < 60 mg/dL, pH < 7.2, and high concentrations of LDH (> 0.45 x normal serum LDH) and amylase (> 200 mg/dL).

In addition to addressing the underlying malignancy, symptomatic malignant pleural effusions can be treated with therapeutic thoracocentesis and, if the effusion is expected to reaccumulate rapidly or frequently, an indwelling pleural catheter or chemical pleurodesis.

images.title: Diffuse nodular pleural thickening
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesotheliomaNodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

answers.content: Nephrotic syndrome
answers.explanation_why: Nephrotic syndrome would result in a clear, transudative pleural effusion from decreased oncotic pressure, not a turbid, exudative pleural effusion. Furthermore, other findings commonly seen in nephrotic syndrome, such as edema, frothy urine, hypertension, or signs of hypocalcemia, are absent in this patient.

answers.content: Tuberculosis
answers.explanation_why: Cough, weight loss, travel to a country with high tuberculosis (TB) incidence, and exudative pleural effusion are consistent with TB. However, isolated, unilateral, nodular pleural lesions are not common x-ray findings in TB. Typical x-ray findings include consolidation, hilar lymphadenopathy, and, in reactivation TB, fibrocaseous cavitary lesions.

images.title: Cavitary lung lesion
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosisA thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.

answers.content: Congestive heart failure
answers.explanation_why: Although the patient has congestive heart failure (CHF), CHF would typically manifest with a clear, transudative effusion from increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries.

images.title: Hydrostatic pulmonary edema
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view)The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing numbness and paresthesias in his hands and feet for the past year. During this period, he has also developed a rash on his palms, soles, and abdomen. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is from India and is visiting his family in the United States. He drinks one to two pints of vodka daily. He works in a battery manufacturing factory. He appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows transverse white lines on his fingernails and toenails. There is spotty hyperpigmentation and nodular confluent thickening over the palms, soles, and abdomen. Muscle strength is decreased in the hands and feet bilaterally. Sensation to vibration, fine touch, and temperature is decreased in the hands and feet. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing numbness and paresthesias in his hands and feet for the past year. During this period, he has also developed a rash on his palms, soles, and abdomen. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is from India and is visiting his family in the United States. He drinks one to two pints of vodka daily. He works in a battery manufacturing factory. He appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows transverse white lines on his fingernails and toenails. There is spotty hyperpigmentation and nodular confluent thickening over the palms, soles, and abdomen. Muscle strength is decreased in the hands and feet bilaterally. Sensation to vibration, fine touch, and temperature is decreased in the hands and feet. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's symptoms suggest chronic poisoning associated with his occupation. The substance most likely responsible has a distinct garlic-like odor.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic arsenic poisoning.

answers.content: Lead poisoning
answers.explanation_why: Chronic lead poisoning is an occupational hazard for battery factory workers and presents with polyneuropathy. However, lead poisoning does not cause hyperkeratosis and lead-induced polyneuropathy is mainly a motor neuropathy. Furthermore, sensory symptoms (e.g., paresthesias) are rare. Other features suggestive of lead poisoning such as intestinal colic, anemia, radial nerve palsy, and Burton line (a blackish‑blue line along the margins of the gums) are also absent in this patient.

answers.content: Alcoholic polyneuropathy
answers.explanation_why: This patient's bilateral distal numbness and weakness along with the history of excessive alcohol use are consistent with alcoholic polyneuropathy, which may be seen in up to 10% of patients with alcohol use disorder. However, this condition explains neither the transverse white lines on nails and nor the palmoplantar hyperkeratosis seen here.

answers.content: Arsenic poisoning
answers.explanation_why:
This patient most likely has chronic arsenic poisoning, which manifests with distal sensorimotor polyneuropathy, white bands across the nails (Mees lines), and hyperkeratosis. Workers in battery factories have an increased risk of being exposed to arsine, a highly toxic gaseous form of arsenic with a distinct garlic-like odor. Elevated arsenic levels in the urine confirm the diagnosis. Treatment consists of chelating agents dimercaprol or succimer (in children).

See “Overview of metal toxicities” table.

answers.content: Cadmium toxicity
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient's occupation puts him at risk of chronic cadmium toxicity, this diagnosis is unlikely because he does not present with typical features such as anosmia, yellowing of teeth, and kidney or lung disease (e.g., tubulointerstitial nephritis or emphysema).

answers.content: Mercury toxicity
answers.explanation_why: Chronic mercury poisoning is an occupational hazard for battery factory workers and manifests with polyneuropathy. However, mercury poisoning does not cause hyperkeratosis or white transverse lines across the nails. Mercury toxicity usually causes intention tremor, erethism, and bluish‑violet discoloration of the gums, which are features this patient does not have.

question_text: An 84-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. The patient lives with her son, who is her primary caregiver. He reports that it is becoming gradually more difficult to care for her. She occasionally has tantrums and there are times when she does not recognize him. She sleeps 6–8 hours throughout the day and is increasingly agitated and confused at night. When the phone, television, or oven beeps she thinks she is at the dentist's office and becomes very anxious. She eats 2–3 meals a day and has a good appetite. She has not fallen. She has not left the home in weeks except for short walks. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism. She takes levothyroxine, aspirin, warfarin, donepezil, verapamil, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin daily.  Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. It is important to the family that the patient continues her care at home. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: An 84-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. The patient lives with her son, who is her primary caregiver. He reports that it is becoming gradually more difficult to care for her. She occasionally has tantrums and there are times when she does not recognize him. She sleeps 6–8 hours throughout the day and is increasingly agitated and confused at night. When the phone, television, or oven beeps she thinks she is at the dentist's office and becomes very anxious. She eats 2–3 meals a day and has a good appetite. She has not fallen. She has not left the home in weeks except for short walks. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism. She takes levothyroxine, aspirin, warfarin, donepezil, verapamil, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. It is important to the family that the patient continues her care at home. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: Sleep disturbances are common in the later stages of Alzheimer disease and can result in anxiety and further disruption of patients' cognitive status.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate recommendation for managing sleep disturbances in Alzheimer disease.

answers.content: Start quetiapine daily
answers.explanation_why: Quetiapine can be used to manage agitation, hallucinations, and insomnia in patients with Alzheimer disease. Although this patient is agitated and has been having difficulty sleeping, pharmacological treatment would only be indicated if nonpharmacological interventions had failed. Behavioral therapies have the same or increased efficacy compared to antipsychotic medications in this patient population.

answers.content: Start lorazepam as needed
answers.explanation_why: Lorazepam is useful for managing symptoms of panic, anxiety, or stress disorders. Although this patient has symptoms of anxiety, nonpharmacological interventions should be attempted prior to resorting to medications. In addition, benzodiazepines are less effective than atypical antipsychotics in treating anxiety in patients with Alzheimer disease.

answers.content: Adhere to a regular sleep schedule
answers.explanation_why: Behavioral and environmental regulation, such as adhering to a regular sleep schedule, maintaining a familiar environment, and removing ambient noise, should always be attempted for patients who are agitated or anxious before resorting to pharmacological treatment. This patient's anxiety is likely a consequence of her dysregulated sleep (i.e., nighttime insomnia and daytime hypersomnia) and resulting disorientation. Efforts to regulate a patient's environment and schedule can help them to remain oriented and can improve symptoms.

answers.content: Discontinue verapamil
answers.explanation_why: Verapamil use is rarely complicated by insomnia or agitation (≤ 1% of cases). Other more likely causes of this patient's symptoms should be addressed before verapamil is discontinued, especially given that this is not a newly prescribed medication. Additionally, if verapamil were discontinued, this patient's atrial fibrillation and/or hypertension may no longer be well-controlled.

answers.content: Frequently play classical music
answers.explanation_why: This patient is already struggling with ambient sounds (e.g., phone, television, oven beeping). Although classical music can have a calming effect, it would contribute to the ambient noise, which may further confuse and disorient this patient.

answers.content: Start haloperidol as needed
answers.explanation_why: Haloperidol is often used to treat agitation or delirium. Although this patient is agitated, nonpharmacological interventions should be attempted prior to resorting to medications. In addition, atypical antipsychotics are usually preferred over typical antipsychotics when treating anxiety and agitation in patients with Alzheimer disease because of the decreased risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

answers.content: Refer for cognitive behavioral therapy
answers.explanation_why: Cognitive behavioral therapy can be helpful for patients with Alzheimer disease, particularly those with anxiety. This step may eventually be an appropriate treatment for this patient, since she has been anxious at times during the day. However, she is having anxiety in the context of an aberrant sleep schedule, leading to disorientation. Environmental changes should first be attempted to manage her symptoms.

question_text:
A previously healthy 44-year-old man is brought by his coworkers to the emergency department 45 minutes after he became light-headed and collapsed while working in the boiler room of a factory. He did not lose consciousness. His coworkers report that 30 minutes prior to collapsing, he told them he was nauseous and had a headache. He appears lethargic. He is not oriented to time, place, or person. His temperature is 41°C (105.8°F), pulse is 133/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 90/52 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. His neck is supple. Infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is administered. A urinary catheter is inserted and dark brown urine is collected. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15 g/dL

Leukocyte count
18,000/mm^3

Platelet count
51,000/mm^3

Serum

Na^+

149 mEq/L

K^+

5.0 mEq/L

Cl^-

98 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
42 mg/dL

Glucose
88 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)
210 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)
250 U/L

Creatine kinase
86,000 U/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 44-year-old man is brought by his coworkers to the emergency department 45 minutes after he became light-headed and collapsed while working in the boiler room of a factory. He did not lose consciousness. His coworkers report that 30 minutes prior to collapsing, he told them he was nauseous and had a headache. He appears lethargic. He is not oriented to time, place, or person. His temperature is 41°C (105.8°F), pulse is 133/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 90/52 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. His neck is supple. Infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is administered. A urinary catheter is inserted and dark brown urine is collected. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15 g/dL Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3 Platelet count 51,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 149 mEq/L K+ 5.0 mEq/L Cl- 98 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 42 mg/dL Glucose 88 mg/dL Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 210 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 250 U/L Creatine kinase 86,000 U/L Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A temperature > 40°C, altered mental status, and rhabdomyolysis (greatly elevated creatine kinase with myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury) in a young, otherwise healthy individual who has been working in a boiler room is suggestive of heatstroke. Heat-induced damage to the vascular endothelium results in the release of cytokines and heat shock proteins that cause leukocytosis (due to a systemic inflammatory response) and DIC, which would explain this patient's thrombocytopenia and multiorgan dysfunction.
learning_objective: Recognize heatstroke, and choose the most appropriate cooling modality.

answers.content: Ice water immersion
answers.explanation_why: The main goal of heatstroke treatment is to reduce the core body temperature to 39.0°C (102°F) to prevent permanent neurologic and organ damage. Ice water immersion is the most effective cooling modality and should be initiated as soon as possible. Cooling measures should be stopped at 39°C to prevent iatrogenic hypothermia.

answers.content: Acetaminophen therapy
answers.explanation_why: Antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen and other NSAIDs) help reduce body temperature by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, leading to a reduction of the prostaglandin E2 concentration in the central nervous system. Prostaglandin E2 concentration increases as a response to endogenous and exogenous pyrogens and displaces the set point of the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center upward. Since increased body temperature in heatstroke develops as a result of impaired heat dissipation, and it is not cytokine-induced, antipyretics are not effective in the treatment of heatstroke. Administration of acetaminophen or NSAIDs may even be harmful as it can exacerbate complications including acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, and the risk of bleeding in patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

answers.content: Platelet transfusion
answers.explanation_why: Platelet transfusions are only considered for patients with a platelet count < 20,000/mm^3. Platelet transfusions are not necessary for a platelet count of 51,000/mm^3 since the risk of adverse events associated with transfusion outweigh the risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia.

answers.content: Lumbar puncture
answers.explanation_why: Lumbar puncture is used to diagnose meningitis, which can also present with fever, headache, and altered mental status. However, CNS infections rarely cause fevers of 41°C (105.8°F) and are typically associated with nuchal rigidity, which this patient does not have.

answers.content: Physostigmine therapy
answers.explanation_why: Physostigmine can treat anticholinergic poisoning, which can manifest with hyperthermia and tachycardia. However, this patient lacks any of the other symptoms associated with anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., nonreactive mydriasis). Furthermore, there is no evidence of ingestion of an anticholinergic agent (e.g., benztropine, Jimson weed).

answers.content: CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the head is used to identify intracranial hemorrhage that could result in neurogenic hyperthermia, headache, nausea, and altered mental status. However, the occupational history (work in a boiler room) and signs of multiorgan dysfunction suggest a heatstroke. The treatment of heatstroke should not be delayed for imaging.

answers.content: Dantrolene
answers.explanation_why: Studies have concluded that dantrolene is not effective in the treatment of heatstroke. Dantrolene is, instead, used to treat patients with malignant hyperthermia, which may manifest with high fever, diaphoresis, hemodynamic instability, increased creatine kinase, and acute kidney injury. However, this patient lacks the muscle rigidity that is usually present with malignant hyperthermia, and has no family history of this condition. Furthermore, it is most commonly associated with the use of anesthetic agents with or without depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., succinylcholine). Malignant hyperthermia can very rarely be triggered by heat exposure or exercise.

answers.content: Hemodialysis
answers.explanation_why: Hemodialysis will very likely be necessary in this patient with rhabdomyolysis, evidence of acute kidney injury, and hyperkalemia. However, a more urgent treatment is indicated before hemodialysis can be initiated.

answers.content: Evaporative cooling
answers.explanation_why: Evaporative cooling is used for patients with heat exhaustion and can be used in heatstroke either as an adjunctive to first-line treatment or if first-line treatment cannot be implemented. Patients with a heatstroke require rapid cooling at a rate of 0.1–0.2°C/min, which typically cannot be achieved with evaporative cooling alone.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergency cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergency cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
hint: It is important for physicians to avoid pressuring the patient in the event of perinatal loss.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to counsel a patient after pregnancy loss.

answers.content: “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”
answers.explanation_why: Empathic communication is critical following perinatal loss. Physicians should acknowledge the loss, validate the patient’s emotions, and offer compassionate support using clear, sensitive language. The PEARLS model and NURS model provide effective frameworks to respond to intense emotions like sadness, anger, or fear. Key steps include naming the emotion, expressing empathy and understanding, and offering supportive statements (e.g., “I’m so sorry for your loss,” “This is a very difficult time”), while avoiding overly personalized remarks such as “I know what you are going through.” When appropriate, parents should be offered the opportunity to see and hold their baby, as this can support the grieving process and reduce the risk of long-term psychiatric complications. These responses legitimize the patient’s grief, foster trust, and allow space to process the loss before further discussion.

answers.content: “Losing a baby is difficult, but I'm sure next time it'll work out.”
answers.explanation_why: While offering optimism may be well-intentioned, prematurely focusing on prospects for future pregnancies or minimizing the unique grief of perinatal loss can make the patient feel that her current experience is invalidated, which may hinder emotional processing and lead to disengagement from needed support.

answers.content: “I'm sorry for your loss. Let's talk about how to move forward from here.”
answers.explanation_why: Moving immediately into solutions or future planning without first acknowledging the current loss overlooks the importance of emotionally validating the patient's experience, neglects her present needs, and may be perceived as dismissive during acute grief, which can disrupt the therapeutic relationship.

answers.content: “Losing a baby is difficult. I can refer you to our grief counselor."
answers.explanation_why: Offering a referral to a grief counselor can be valuable as part of ongoing care, but immediately directing the patient toward outside help without first personally validating her emotional state misses an essential opportunity to connect empathically at the most vulnerable time and may be experienced as distancing.

answers.content: “Losing a baby is difficult. I know what you're going through.”
answers.explanation_why: Statements that presume to know precisely what a patient is experiencing, even when offered in empathy, risk minimizing the individual’s unique perspective and replacing genuine support with assumed understanding, which can unintentionally make the patient feel isolated or misunderstood during her grief.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of difficulty sleeping and poor appetite for the past 4 weeks. During this period, he has also had persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating on tasks, because of which he has been reprimanded at work for poor performance. Over the past 3 years, he has often had such phases, with a maximum symptom-free gap of one month between each of them. His behavior is causing a strain in his relationships with his wife and children. His mother died 4 months ago from breast cancer. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of difficulty sleeping and poor appetite for the past 4 weeks. During this period, he has also had persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating on tasks, because of which he has been reprimanded at work for poor performance. Over the past 3 years, he has often had such phases, with a maximum symptom-free gap of one month between each of them. His behavior is causing a strain in his relationships with his wife and children. His mother died 4 months ago from breast cancer. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient's periods of remission have lasted for ≤ 2 consecutive months.
learning_objective: Recognize persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia).

answers.content: Persistent depressive disorder
answers.explanation_why: This patient has depressed mood as well as difficulty sleeping, poor appetite, and poor concentration, all of which are causing psychosocial impairment. These symptoms have been present most of the time for ≥ 2 years in the absence of substance use. Therefore, this patient meets the criteria for persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia). He is likely to benefit from treatment with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and/or psychotherapy.

images.title: Symptom-duration criteria for the diagnosis of mood disorders

answers.content: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood
answers.explanation_why: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood can manifest with sadness, sleep disturbances, poor appetite, and poor concentration. However, this diagnosis requires the development of depressed symptoms within 3 months of a clear psychosocial stressor and resolution of symptoms within 6 months after termination of the stressor. There is no evidence to suggest that this patient's mood is a reaction to a stressor, and he has had the symptoms for years.

answers.content: Bipolar affective disorder
answers.explanation_why: Depressive episodes in bipolar disorder can manifest with sadness, sleep disturbances, poor appetite, and poor concentration. However, diagnostic criteria for bipolar disorder require the presence of at least one manic or hypomanic episode, which this patient lacks.

answers.content: Major depressive disorder
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient has had several symptoms of major depressive disorder (MDD) for > 2 weeks (sleep disturbance, poor appetite, and poor concentration), he does not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for a MDD, which would require ≥ 5 of the SIGECAPS symptoms.

answers.content: Persistent complex bereavement disorder
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient lost his mother 4 months ago, there is no evidence of persistent yearning for her, intense sorrow in response to the death, preoccupation with the deceased or the circumstances of her death, which is required for the diagnosis of persistent complex bereavement disorder. Furthermore, his symptoms began years before the death of his mother.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of mild fatigue and dizziness for the past 2 days. She has not been to work since yesterday due to her symptoms. She says she has "very high blood sugar” and has had similar episodes often in the past 2 years, for which she has visited multiple doctors around the city. She has also purchased a home glucose monitoring device, which she uses daily. Since the symptoms began, she has become socially withdrawn and spends much of her time at home researching diabetes on the internet. One week ago, she took a day off work because of her symptoms. She is not on any treatment. She has had three laboratory test reports that all show normal fasting and post-meal blood glucose levels. Her father and brother have type 2 diabetes mellitus. She appears anxious. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Random serum glucose is 128 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of mild fatigue and dizziness for the past 2 days. She has not been to work since yesterday due to her symptoms. She says she has "very high blood sugar” and has had similar episodes often in the past 2 years, for which she has visited multiple doctors around the city. She has also purchased a home glucose monitoring device, which she uses daily. Since the symptoms began, she has become socially withdrawn and spends much of her time at home researching diabetes on the internet. One week ago, she took a day off work because of her symptoms. She is not on any treatment. She has had three laboratory test reports that all show normal fasting and post-meal blood glucose levels. Her father and brother have type 2 diabetes mellitus. She appears anxious. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Random serum glucose is 128 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient is preoccupied with having diabetes and has visited multiple doctors over the past 2 years for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize illness anxiety disorder.

answers.content: Somatic symptom disorder
answers.explanation_why: Patients with somatic symptom disorder have symptoms that cause significant distress and they often undergo extensive testing without a diagnosis being found. However, patients with somatic symptom disorder tend to have physical symptoms (e.g., heartburn, headache, abdominal pain) which must be present for at least 6 months to meet diagnostic criteria (according to the DSM-5). This patient is preoccupied with having diabetes, which is likely the result of her symptoms.

answers.content: Factitious disorder
answers.explanation_why: Patients with factitious disorder can exhibit a preoccupation with having an illness. However, these patients will intentionally falsify their disease (e.g., inject insulin to induce hypoglycemia) to assume the role of a sick person. This patient has consistently normal test results without evidence of falsified disease.

answers.content: Malingering
answers.explanation_why: Malingering patients may present with vague complaints (e.g., dizziness, fatigue) that cannot be verified by medical testing (e.g., normal fasting blood glucose levels). Malingering patients intentionally feign their symptoms to achieve some external gain, such as this patient possibly taking sick leave to avoid work. However, malingering symptoms are usually not specific to a certain medical diagnosis. Additionally, they are not preoccupied with excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., daily use of a glucometer, extensive internet research, numerous doctor's visits) over such a long period of time. This constellation of features is more consistent with another diagnosis.

answers.content: Normal health-related anxiety
answers.explanation_why: Patients can experience health-related anxiety as a response to a serious medical condition being revealed as a possibility (e.g., the potential of developing diabetes with a strong family history). However, the anxiety should be proportionate to the seriousness of the medical condition and should resolve over 2–3 months.

answers.content: Obsessive-compulsive disorder
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient may have intrusive thoughts about having diabetes (i.e., obsessions) with associated compulsive behaviors (e.g., checking the internet, seeking reassurance from physicians), she lacks the stereotyped, repetitive behaviors that tend to characterize obsessive-compulsive disorder (e.g., repeatedly checking the door is locked). Furthermore, there is no evidence that her obsessions extend beyond fears of having an illness, which suggests another diagnosis.

answers.content: Unipolar major depression
answers.explanation_why: Patients with unipolar major depression can obsess over their physical health, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not display a depressed mood or anhedonia, which is required for diagnosis of major depressive disorder.

answers.content: Illness anxiety disorder
answers.explanation_why: This patient exhibits a persistent preoccupation with having diabetes for ≥ 6 months, despite no clinical evidence to support this diagnosis. She exhibits excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., daily use of a glucometer, extensive internet research, numerous doctor's visits) and has only mild somatic symptoms (e.g., fatigue). Based on these findings, she most likely has illness anxiety disorder (previously referred to as hypochondriasis). Treatment for illness anxiety disorder includes regular scheduled primary care physician visits to address patient concerns and cognitive behavioral therapy. Comorbid psychiatric diseases should also be treated if present.

answers.content: Impaired glucose homeostasis
answers.explanation_why: This patient's family history puts her at risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus, and the early stages of this disease can manifest with normal random blood sugar, as seen in this patient. However, there should be evidence of at least one abnormal blood glucose level in the past 2 years of testing. Furthermore, this patient's intense preoccupation with having diabetes suggests another diagnosis. A single random blood glucose measurement of ≥ 200 mg/dL would establish the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

question_text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-month history of fatigue, intermittent fever, and weakness. Results from a peripheral blood smear taken during his evaluation are indicative of possible acute myeloid leukemia. Bone marrow aspiration and subsequent cytogenetic studies confirm the diagnosis. The physician sets aside an appointed time-slot and arranges a meeting in a quiet office to inform the patient about the diagnosis and discuss his options. He has been encouraged to bring someone along to the appointment if he wanted. He comes to the office at the appointed time with his daughter. He appears relaxed, with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate opening statement in this situation?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-month history of fatigue, intermittent fever, and weakness. Results from a peripheral blood smear taken during his evaluation are indicative of possible acute myeloid leukemia. Bone marrow aspiration and subsequent cytogenetic studies confirm the diagnosis. The physician sets aside an appointed time-slot and arranges a meeting in a quiet office to inform the patient about the diagnosis and discuss his options. He has been encouraged to bring someone along to the appointment if he wanted. He comes to the office at the appointed time with his daughter. He appears relaxed, with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate opening statement in this situation?
hint: When delivering bad news, physicians should follow the SPIKES protocol.
learning_objective: Recognize the SPIKES protocol for delivering serious news to patients.

answers.content: "I may need to refer you to a blood cancer specialist because of your diagnosis. You may need chemotherapy or radiotherapy, which we are not equipped for.”
answers.explanation_why: This statement, which is a summary of the management strategy, is an important part of delivering serious news. However, such a statement should only be made after delivering the diagnosis, discussing the prognosis, and responding to the patient with empathy if emotions are triggered by the news. If the patient's emotions (e.g., shock, anger, grief, denial) are not addressed, the patient may become resistant to any information that is provided regarding the management plan.

answers.content: "Your lab reports show that you have an acute myeloid leukemia."
answers.explanation_why: This statement very bluntly and, therefore, inappropriately delivers the diagnosis to the patient. Disclosing the diagnosis is an important part of delivering serious news but the diagnosis should be communicated in a step-by-step manner that involves reviewing the examination and diagnostic findings with the patient and ensuring that he/she understands what is being said at each step. Technical terms such as “leukemia” should be explained in a way that the layman understands. Moreover, the diagnosis should only be disclosed after obtaining the patient's invitation to discuss it. Seeking the patient's permission to deliver the diagnosis provides an important clue on how much the patient wants to know. This clue from the patient can also reduce the physician's anxiety at delivering serious news.

answers.content: "What is your understanding of the reasons we did bone marrow aspiration and cytogenetic studies?"
answers.explanation_why:
This statement contains an assessment of the patient's perception of his situation, which is the second step in delivering serious news according to the SPIKES protocol (P = Perception) after appropriate steps have been taken to set up the interview (= S). Assessing the patient's perception provides an opportunity for clearing up misconceptions and gauging the patient's reaction. It furthermore helps determine the nature and amount of information required to deliver the diagnosis and communicate a management plan. The next step after assessing the patient's perception is to seek the patient's invitation (= I) to discuss the diagnosis.

See “SPIKES protocol overview” table.

answers.content: "Would you like to know all the details of your diagnosis, or would you prefer I just explain to you what our options are?"
answers.explanation_why:
This statement, which obtains the patient's permission to deliver the diagnosis, is an important part of communicating serious news. However, as an opening statement in the process before the diagnosis has been delivered, it is inappropriate. Such a question should only be asked after the interview has been properly prepared and the patient's perception of his/her situation has been assessed.

Discussing information disclosure at the time of ordering tests would be a more suitable time to pose this question to a patient. This would also help cue the physician to plan the next discussion (delivering serious news in case of adverse test results) with the patient.

answers.content: "You must be curious and maybe even anxious about the results of your tests."
answers.explanation_why: This statement addresses the patient's emotions, which is an important part of delivering serious news. However, apart from the inappropriate tone, making such a statement before telling the patient his/her diagnosis and prognosis would only trigger anxiety and distress.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The scalp is covered with telangiectasias, light brown papules, and erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques. This condition is the result of chronic, unprotected sun exposure (e.g., from working outdoors).
learning_objective: Recognize actinic keratosis.

answers.content: Seborrheic keratosis
answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor in the older population. However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, it manifests as darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and “stuck-on.” Also, the lesions tend to involve the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and forearms, rather than the scalp.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

answers.content: Basal cell carcinoma
answers.explanation_why: Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most common skin tumors and occur on areas of skin exposed to sun. Given his former occupation, this patient is at increased risk of developing BCCs. However, in contrast to this patient's lesions, which manifest as erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques, BCCs present as pearly, indurated, and nodular lesions with a rolled border and a central depression (crater) with ulceration.

images.title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
images.description: An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

answers.content: Keratoacanthoma
answers.explanation_why: While keratoacanthomas tend to occur in older patients who have had chronic sun exposure, such as this patient, they manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months. In this patient, the multiple erythematous lesions with scales found on the scalp are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

images.title: Preauricular keratoacanthoma
images.description: An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

answers.content: Tinea capitis
answers.explanation_why: Tinea capitis affects the scalp and manifests as round, scaly plaques with broken hair shafts or alopecia in the affected areas. Although this patient has mild itching, tinea capitis is usually associated with intense pruritus. Also, tinea capitis mainly affects small children and generally occurs in areas that contain hair follicles, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this 68-year-old bald man.

images.title: Tinea capitis
images.description:
Localization: scalp
Primary lesion: nodule
Description: slightly elevated, reddened, papular, and pustular nodule with scaling and hair loss, caused by the dermatophyte Microsporum gypseum

answers.content: Actinic keratosis
answers.explanation_why:
Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that occurs on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, ears, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. The lesions typically grow back after they are scraped off. Initially, actinic keratosis manifests as small lesions with a central scale and a rough surface, giving them a sandpaper-like texture on palpation. Later, the lesions may grow and become erythematous and scaly, as seen in this patient. The risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma depends on the degree of epithelial dysplasia, but it is < 1% per year. Occasionally, hyperkeratosis may turn preexisting actinic keratosis lesions into cutaneous horns.

Actinic keratosis is usually a clinical diagnosis, although for lesions that are ≥ 1 cm, grow rapidly, or do not respond to treatment, a biopsy is necessary to distinguish it from squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment options include cryotherapy for isolated lesions, or 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, or photodynamic therapy in patients with multiple lesions.

images.title: Actinic keratosis of the scalp
images.description: Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adultMultiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

answers.content: Bowen disease
answers.explanation_why: Bowen disease is commonly associated with sun exposure and may be similar in appearance to this patient's lesion. However, it usually manifests as a solitary lesion rather than the multiple ill-defined, confluent lesions seen on this patient's scalp. While Bowen disease cannot be entirely excluded without pathologic examination, based on the appearance of the lesions, another diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

answers.content: Amelanotic melanoma
answers.explanation_why: Amelanotic melanomas are associated with UV exposure and may be difficult to recognize, but they usually manifest as a pink or red macule, plaque, or nodule. Multiple erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques with a rough texture suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Amelanotic melanoma
images.description: A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

images.title: Actinic keratosis
images.description: The entire hairless portion of the scalp is covered with telangiectasia, light brown papules, and yellow-brownish, hyperkeratotic plaques.This appearance is typical of actinic keratoses.
