question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent shortness of breath while going upstairs and walking his dog. It began about 1 month ago and seems to be getting worse. He has also developed a dry cough. He has not had any wheezing, fevers, chills, recent weight loss, or shortness of breath at rest. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma, for which he was treated with chemotherapy and radiation to the chest 7 years ago. He also has hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. Ten years ago, he retired from work in the shipbuilding industry. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 21. Vital signs are within normal limits. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A plain x-ray of the chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent shortness of breath while going upstairs and walking his dog. It began about 1 month ago and seems to be getting worse. He has also developed a dry cough. He has not had any wheezing, fevers, chills, recent weight loss, or shortness of breath at rest. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma, for which he was treated with chemotherapy and radiation to the chest 7 years ago. He also has hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. Ten years ago, he retired from work in the shipbuilding industry. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 21. Vital signs are within normal limits. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A plain x-ray of the chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
hint: Calcified pleural plaques and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray suggest asbestosis.
learning_objective: Recognize occupational exposure as a risk factor for asbestosis.

answers.content: Occupational exposure
answers.explanation_why: Occupational exposure is the strongest risk factor for developing asbestosis. Occupations such as shipbuilding (as in this patient) or those that involve working with textiles, cement, or insulation put workers at higher risk of inhaling asbestos fibers. Exposure to asbestos can lead to complications like pulmonary fibrosis, respiratory failure, and malignancy (especially bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma). This patient's history of smoking further increases his risk of developing lung cancer.

answers.content: Smoking history
answers.explanation_why: A history of smoking does not increase the risk of developing asbestosis. However, patients with asbestosis who smoke have a more rapidly progressive disease course and an increased risk of lung cancer.

answers.content: Advanced age
answers.explanation_why: There has been no evidence to suggest that advanced age is a risk factor for developing asbestosis.

answers.content: Family history
answers.explanation_why: Family history is not a risk factor for asbestosis, as it is not a condition that can be inherited.

answers.content: Radiation therapy
answers.explanation_why: Prior radiation therapy, especially exposure to ionizing radiation in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, is associated with a statistically significant increase in the risk of mesothelioma. While mesothelioma can be a complication of asbestosis, asbestosis cannot be caused by radiation therapy.

question_text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and a cough productive of a small amount of grayish-white phlegm. The cough had been initially nonproductive. He has not had fever or chest pain. He is originally from China and visits his family there once every year. He has worked as a car salesman for 15 years and worked in a shipyard before that for 22 years. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years but stopped 25 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Fine expiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening in both lungs. A photomicrograph from a sputum sample is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and a cough productive of a small amount of grayish-white phlegm. The cough had been initially nonproductive. He has not had fever or chest pain. He is originally from China and visits his family there once every year. He has worked as a car salesman for 15 years and worked in a shipyard before that for 22 years. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years but stopped 25 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Fine expiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening in both lungs. A photomicrograph from a sputum sample is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient sputum sample shows an elongated, yellow rod (i.e., an asbestos body).
learning_objective: Recognize asbestosis, and recall its expected pulmonary function test finding.

answers.content: Increased alveolar-arterial gradient
answers.explanation_why: This patient’s presentation (exertional dyspnea, cough, bibasilar crackles) and diagnostic test findings (asbestos bodies on sputum analysis, pleural thickening on chest x-ray) indicate asbestosis. Patients with asbestosis may develop interstitial lung disease with parenchymal fibrosis, which impairs the diffusion of oxygen across the alveolocapillary membrane, causing an increase in the alveolar-arterial gradient.

answers.content: Bloody pleural effusion
answers.explanation_why: A bloody pleural effusion could be seen in mesothelioma caused by asbestosis. This patient's occupational history certainly puts him at risk for developing malignancy. However, he is currently not exhibiting signs associated with mesothelioma, such as fever, sweats, weight loss, or fatigue. Also, there are no signs on the physical exam or imaging that indicate effusion in this patient.

answers.content: Positive interferon-γ release assay
answers.explanation_why: A positive interferon-γ release assay would indicate infection with M. tuberculosis. This patient has a considerable risk of tuberculosis since he is originally from China, a country with a high incidence of the disease, and visits yearly. However, active pulmonary tuberculosis typically manifests with a productive cough (possibly hemoptysis), as well as fever and weight loss. Furthermore, pleural thickening and the absence of hilar lymphadenopathy or cavitation on x-ray are not consistent with this diagnosis.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.content: Increased total lung capacity
answers.explanation_why: Lung capacity can be increased in obstructive lung diseases such as emphysema. This patient may have mild obstructive lung changes from his smoking history. However, the findings on x-ray and from the sputum sample indicate a restrictive disease that would result in a decreased lung capacity.

answers.content: Concave flow-volume loop
answers.explanation_why: A concave flow-volume loop is seen in obstructive lung disease and is due to increased resistance during expiration. In a patient with suspected asbestosis, the flow-volume loop would be expected to show a restrictive pattern. This means it would have a normal shape, but a decreased overall volume.

answers.content: Increased diffusing capacity
answers.explanation_why: Diffusing capacity (DL_CO) is increased when gases like oxygen, or carbon monoxide in the pulmonary test, are easily transported across the capillary membrane within the alveoli. This can be seen in bronchial asthma, obesity, and polycythemia vera. However, this patient's interstitial lung disease causes fibrosis and therefore thickening of capillary membrane, which reduces diffusing capacity.

images.title: Asbestosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a sputum sample (H&E stain; high magnification)A yellow-brown asbestos body is visible (green overlay). It is coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material and has a characteristic dumbbell shape (illustration).

question_text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of severe right-sided flank pain, fever, and vomiting. He has a history of gout, benign prostate hyperplasia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with allopurinol, tamsulosin, and metformin. Urinalysis shows pyuria, leukocyturia, and WBC casts. Results of blood and urine cultures are pending. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and admitted for empiric treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. After 4 days, his symptoms have continued to worsen. He is somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. He is transferred to the intensive care unit and vasopressor therapy is initiated. The physician informs the patient's wife that her husband has developed urosepsis as a complication of his urinary tract infection and that advanced life support may become necessary. A written advance directive provided by the patient's primary care physician includes a do-not-intubate (DNI) order, which was verbally confirmed by the patient upon admission. There is no medical power of attorney. The patient's wife says she wants full life support in case of cardiorespiratory arrest. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of severe right-sided flank pain, fever, and vomiting. He has a history of gout, benign prostate hyperplasia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with allopurinol, tamsulosin, and metformin. Urinalysis shows pyuria, leukocyturia, and WBC casts. Results of blood and urine cultures are pending. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and admitted for empiric treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. After 4 days, his symptoms have continued to worsen. He is somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. He is transferred to the intensive care unit and vasopressor therapy is initiated. The physician informs the patient's wife that her husband has developed urosepsis as a complication of his urinary tract infection and that advanced life support may become necessary. A written advance directive provided by the patient's primary care physician includes a do-not-intubate (DNI) order, which was verbally confirmed by the patient upon admission. There is no medical power of attorney. The patient's wife says she wants full life support in case of cardiorespiratory arrest. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: A DNI order expresses a patient's wish to decline the placement of a breathing tube in the event of cardiac or respiratory arrest.
learning_objective: Recognize how to honor a patient's advance directive regarding intubation.

answers.content: “I will perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if needed, but I cannot intubate your husband.”
answers.explanation_why:
A living will is a legal document that expresses a patient's wishes regarding health care and should be used to guide treatment if the patient loses decision-making capacity. The patient's wishes should be honored even if family members disagree. This patient's living will includes a DNI order that he confirmed upon admission; therefore, he should not be intubated. Because this patient does not have a DNR order, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and other resuscitative measures may be performed if needed. Patients who retain their decision-making capacity may revoke advance directives at any time. If a patient is incapacitated, only a durable medical power of attorney can override an advance directive, living will, DNI, or DNR.

A patient's code status (e.g., the presence of a DNR or DNI) should be confirmed verbally with the patient or their appropriate surrogate and documented at each hospital admission.

answers.content: “This may be difficult for you, but your request is unethical. You should respect your husband's wishes.”
answers.explanation_why: Although the patient's wishes regarding advanced life support should be respected, it would be disrespectful to call his wife's request “unethical.” Physicians should treat patients and relatives with empathy and refrain from making derogatory statements.

answers.content: “I have to respect your husband's wishes and will only provide comfort measures.”
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient has a DNI order, he does not have a DNR order, which means that cardiopulmonary resuscitation and other resuscitative measures may be used. Providing comfort measures alone is therefore inappropriate.

answers.content: “I can only intubate your husband if you obtain a court order to revoke his advance directive.”
answers.explanation_why: This patient has a DNI order, which he verbally confirmed upon admission. Seeking a court order to override his wishes is inappropriate.

answers.content: “If you can confirm that this decision is in your husband's best interest, I will provide full life support.”
answers.explanation_why: If no advance directive (living will or medical power of attorney) exists, a next of kin (e.g., spouse, adult child, parent, sibling) should be appointed as a default surrogate who can make treatment decisions on the patient's behalf. This patient has a living will that includes a DNI order. Therefore, providing full life support is not appropriate.

question_text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician for an examination prior to a scheduled cholecystectomy. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His mother had chronic granulomatous disease of the lung. He works in a glass manufacturing plant. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 38 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician for an examination prior to a scheduled cholecystectomy. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His mother had chronic granulomatous disease of the lung. He works in a glass manufacturing plant. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 38 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a peripherally located solitary pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray.
learning_objective: Recognize a solitary pulmonary nodule, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.content: Perform arterial blood gas analysis
answers.explanation_why: Arterial blood gas analysis is part of the normal workup for many lung diseases in a symptomatic patient, especially in the case of acid-base disorders. This patient, however, has normal vital signs, and physical examination and laboratory studies are within normal limits.

answers.content: Perform CT-guided biopsy
answers.explanation_why: A CT-guided biopsy is indicated for a patient who has a solitary lung nodule measuring > 8 mm on a CT scan and has multiple high-risk features (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking, occupational carcinogen exposure, family history of lung cancer) or avid uptake on a PET-CT scan. Although this patient has a few high-risk clinical features (e.g., advanced age, smoking history), a different step is indicated before a CT scan or CT-guided biopsy is considered.

answers.content: Perform diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide
answers.explanation_why: Diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is useful in differentiating intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary causes of restrictive lung disease. This patient's occupational history of glass manufacturing puts him at significant risk for silicosis, which can manifest with a decreased DLCO. Although silicosis can also manifest with solitary lesions, particularly in the upper and middle regions of the lungs, this patient does not have signs of silicosis, such as dyspnea upon exertion, productive cough, or classic x-ray findings (i.e., eggshell calcifications or bilateral ground-glass opacities).

answers.content: Measure angiotensin-converting enzyme
answers.explanation_why: ACE levels are commonly elevated in patients with sarcoidosis and can be used for monitoring disease progression and treatment. Patients often present with dry cough and exertional dyspnea, peripheral lymphadenopathy, and skin findings such as lupus pernio. While this patient is at a higher risk for sarcoidosis given his positive family history of chronic granulomatous disease, he is currently asymptomatic and a chest x-ray would show hilar lymphadenopathy with or without bilateral reticular opacities rather than a solitary pulmonary nodule.

images.title: Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosisThe pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

answers.content: Perform high-resolution computed tomography
answers.explanation_why: High-resolution CT can be useful in the diagnosis of restrictive lung diseases. This patient's occupational history of glass manufacturing puts him at significant risk for silicosis, which can also manifest with solitary pulmonary lesions. However, patients with these lesions typically present with dyspnea upon exertion, productive cough, and classic x-ray findings such as eggshell calcifications or bilateral ground-glass opacities, which are all absent here.

answers.content: Request previous chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Requesting a previous chest x-ray is the most appropriate first step in the management of a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule, especially when the risk of malignancy is high (age > 60 years, history of smoking). Old imaging studies are used to assess for new changes on the current radiograph (e.g., additional nodules, enlargement). Following the review of previous imaging or if no previous chest x-ray is available, a low-dose CT scan is indicated to assess for nodule size, location, and signs of malignancy.

answers.content: Perform positron emission tomography
answers.explanation_why: Positron emission tomography can be used to evaluate incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodules that are ≥ 8 mm in size with a low or intermediate risk of malignancy. This patient’s nodule does meet the size criteria, but there are factors present that indicate a high risk of malignancy (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking). Furthermore, another step in management is indicated first in any patient with an incidental solitary pulmonary nodule on x-ray.

answers.content: Repeat x-ray in 12 months
answers.explanation_why: A repeat x-ray in 12 months is insufficient for this patient who has risk factors for lung cancer and a solitary lung nodule on chest radiograph.

images.title: Pulmonary nodule
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinomaA solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before going to sleep. After removing the contact lenses, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and watering of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. Corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before going to sleep. After removing the contact lenses, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and watering of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. Corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
hint: Eye pain, excessive tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation that appear acutely after the removal of an overworn contact lens are suggestive of a corneal abrasion. Although visual acuity is preserved in corneal abrasion, this patient has a previous history of wearing contact lenses and decreased visual acuity in both eyes, suggesting a refractive error.
learning_objective: Recognize corneal abrasion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.content: Fluorescein examination
answers.explanation_why: Fluorescein examination is the test of choice for identifying a corneal abrasion. Corneal abrasions are defects in the corneal epithelium that often occur secondary to corneal trauma. Removal of contact lenses after wearing them overnight is likely to have caused a corneal abrasion in this patient. Fluorescein dye specifically stains the epithelial defects, making them easily identifiable on slit lamp, ophthalmoscopic, or Wood lamp examination. In addition, the conjunctival surface of the eyelids should be examined to rule out a foreign body such as a retained contact lens. In corneal abrasion, photophobia can be attributed to spastic miosis resulting from the trigeminal sensation of the cornea.

images.title: Corneal abrasion highlighted by fluorescein staining
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the left eye with fluorescein stainingA small area of green staining (black arrow) confirms a corneal abrasion. Significant conjunctival injection is also visible.

answers.content: Ocular ultrasonography
answers.explanation_why: Ocular ultrasonography can visualize structures in the back of the eye, especially when examination of the fundus cannot be performed due to opacities in the anterior segment (e.g., bacterial keratitis, dense cataracts), which is, however, not the case here. Abnormalities that can be detected on ultrasound include retinal detachments and vitreous hemorrhage. This patient does not complain of flashes of light, floaters, or sudden loss of vision to suggest any of these pathologies.

answers.content: Gonioscopy
answers.explanation_why: Gonioscopy is useful in diagnosing acute angle closure glaucoma. Patients would typically present with severe ocular pain that does not resolve on the application of a topical anesthetic. Examination would show a mid-fixed dilated pupil and conjunctival injection. As this patient has a normal pupillary exam and ocular pain that resolved with the administration of an anesthetic, glaucoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

answers.content: CT scan of the orbit
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the orbit is used to evaluate for an intraocular foreign body and/or an open globe injury. While patients with an intraocular foreign body or an open globe injury typically present with pain, decreased visual acuity of the affected eye, not both eyes, is also expected. Patients with an open globe injury usually have additional findings of an irregular pupil and a relative afferent pupillary defect. In addition, this patient has no history to suggest blunt or penetrating ocular trauma.

answers.content: Ocular discharge cultures
answers.explanation_why: Ocular discharge cultures may be useful in patients with acute bacterial conjunctivitis or bacterial keratitis. Both of these conditions can occur in contact lens wearers secondary to inadequate contact lens hygiene. Bacterial conjunctivitis and keratitis manifest with tearing and foreign body sensation. However, severe purulent discharge and conjunctival injection are also seen in bacterial conjunctivitis. In keratitis, the visual acuity of the affected eye is decreased and, if severe, corneal edema and hypopyon would be present.

images.title: Bacterial conjunctivitis
images.description: Left eyeThere is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

question_text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's hands show signs of frostbite following prolonged exposure to the cold.
learning_objective: Recognize frostbite, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.content: Debridement of the affected tissue
answers.explanation_why: Debridement may be indicated in the management of frostbite. While this patient's hands show features of frostbite, surgical treatment with debridement or amputation should not be performed until all nonviable tissue becomes clearly demarcated, a process that usually takes 3–4 weeks.

answers.content: Intra-arterial administration of tissue plasminogen activator
answers.explanation_why: Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), in combination with heparin, is indicated in the treatment of frostbite in patients without contraindications for anticoagulation therapy. tPA acts to prevent vascular thrombosis in frostbitten tissue, but it is usually reserved for patients at high risk for a life-altering amputation. This patient has cyanosis of the distal phalanges only, which will likely be treated with a soft-tissue amputation, or no amputation at all. A different step in management is more urgent at this time.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid is indicated to treat individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). Since this patient is only borderline hypothermic, passive rewarming measures (e.g., removing wet clothing, warm room) are sufficient and IV crystalloid infusion is not required.

answers.content: Extracorporeal blood rewarming
answers.explanation_why: Extracorporeal blood rewarming may be used to manage individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). While it is the most effective method of active rewarming, it is an invasive procedure associated with a number of risks (e.g., hemorrhages, stroke) and is reserved for management of the most severe cases. This patient would benefit from passive rewarming measures (e.g., warm clothing, blankets) but does not require treatment for severe hypothermia.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of antibiotics
answers.explanation_why: In an individual with frostbite, treatment with intravenous antibiotics and sterile dressings is indicated to manage bacterial superinfections. Since this patient shows no signs of infection (e.g., localized swelling, erythema, fever, leukocytosis), antibiotic treatment is not required.

answers.content: Immersion of affected extremities in warm water
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with suspected frostbite, active rewarming of the affected extremity is indicated to avoid further tissue damage. The affected extremity should be immersed in a warm (preferably 37–39°C), circulating water bath. Passive rewarming is also helpful (especially in patients with mild hypothermia) and includes removing any wet clothes, covering with blankets, and increasing the temperature of the room.

In patients with concomitant moderate-to-severe hypothermia, treatment of hypothermia should take priority because it can be acutely life-threatening. The trunk should be warmed prior to the extremities, as peripheral vasodilation may lead to a return of cold blood to the heart, which increases the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fever and right upper quadrant pain. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows gallbladder wall thickening and cholelithiasis. She is diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and scheduled for an emergency cholecystectomy. During surgery, the surgeon transects the common bile duct rather than the cystic duct. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the surgeon's mistake?
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fever and right upper quadrant pain. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows gallbladder wall thickening and cholelithiasis. She is diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and scheduled for an emergency cholecystectomy. During surgery, the surgeon transects the common bile duct rather than the cystic duct. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the surgeon's mistake?
hint: This event occurred at the level of direct contact between the surgeon and the patient and had an immediate impact.
learning_objective: Recognize the characteristics of an active error in the clinical setting.

answers.content: Active error
answers.explanation_why:
An active error (sharp end flaw) is one that is performed by the operator, immediately apparent, and typically noticed first by the individual who committed it. A surgeon who transects the common bile duct instead of the cystic duct has made an active error.

This error is also a preventable adverse event that would have likely been avoided with meticulous surgical dissection. If the wrong duct were transected because of poor visualization, converting to an open cholecystectomy may have prevented the error.

See "Overview of medical error types" table.

answers.content: Ameliorable adverse event
answers.explanation_why: An ameliorable adverse event is an unintended consequence of medical management that is unavoidable but could have been less severe if a different protocol were followed. In contrast, transection of the wrong duct during surgery is always avoidable if the surgeon is properly trained and sufficiently exposed both structures to correctly identify which one to cut.

answers.content: Nonpreventable adverse event
answers.explanation_why: A nonpreventable adverse event occurs because of factors entirely outside a physician's control. An example is a total knee replacement that becomes infected after a patient scrapes the knee against a dirty metal bar after hospital discharge. In contrast, transection of the wrong duct during surgery is always preventable if the surgeon is properly trained and has sufficiently exposed both structures to correctly identify which one to cut.

answers.content: Sentinel event
answers.explanation_why: A sentinel event is identified as the critical step or factor during the course of a patient's care that led to an unacceptable complication (e.g., serious patient injury or death). Not every complication has a sentinel event, and not every sentinel event is caused by an error. Although transection of the wrong duct in this patient is due to surgeon error, the overall course of this patient's care will need to be further evaluated to determine if this error will later be defined as a sentinel event (because of further patient complications, injuries, and/or death).

answers.content: Anchoring error
answers.explanation_why: An anchoring error is the result of psychological anchoring, in which a healthcare professional is more likely to rely on an initial impression, examination, and/or diagnosis to make a decision. For example, if a physician who initially diagnoses a patient with gout continues to defend that diagnosis despite the growth of bacteria from synovial fluid aspirate, the physician is making an anchoring error. There is no evidence in this case that the transection of the wrong duct was the result of anchoring to an incorrect initial examination or diagnosis.

answers.content: Blunt end flaw
answers.explanation_why: A latent error (blunt end flaw) is typically caused by a failure of design and/or of the larger system in question (e.g., the hospital). An example of a latent error is if the patient developed a bleed after her cholecystectomy because the hospital purchased low-quality surgical staples. In contrast, the transection of the wrong duct is performed in real-time by the surgeon leading the operation.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department of a busy suburban hospital because of a 1-week history of nausea and vomiting. She also has had intermittent fevers and headaches during the past 5 weeks. She does not have a stiff neck or sensitivity to light. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected for analysis. On the way to the laboratory, the physician loses the CSF specimens. The physician decides that a repeat lumbar puncture should be performed. Before giving consent for the second procedure, the patient asks what the results are from the specimens obtained earlier. Which of the following responses by the physician is the most appropriate?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department of a busy suburban hospital because of a 1-week history of nausea and vomiting. She also has had intermittent fevers and headaches during the past 5 weeks. She does not have a stiff neck or sensitivity to light. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected for analysis. On the way to the laboratory, the physician loses the CSF specimens. The physician decides that a repeat lumbar puncture should be performed. Before giving consent for the second procedure, the patient asks what the results are from the specimens obtained earlier. Which of the following responses by the physician is the most appropriate?
hint: The loss of the first CSF specimens constitutes a medical error.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate way to disclose a medical error to a patient.

answers.content: "I sincerely apologize; I misplaced the specimens. Thankfully, this is not a big issue because I can easily obtain more fluid."
answers.explanation_why: Although this response does disclose that the physician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it minimizes the gravity of the situation. Physicians should disclose errors in objective terms and refrain from placing a value judgment on the significance of the error because each patient will have a unique response.

answers.content: "I was unable to obtain results from the earlier tests because I misplaced the specimens. I sincerely apologize for the mistake."
answers.explanation_why: This response is the most appropriate way of disclosing the medical error to the patient. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly admitting the error, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the physician-patient relationship and patient safety.

answers.content: "I was not able to get the answers we needed from the first set of tests, so we need to repeat them."
answers.explanation_why: This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it may mislead the patient into believing that the tests were performed but inconclusive.

answers.content: "Unfortunately, I was not able to get enough fluid in the specimens to perform the tests."
answers.explanation_why: This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it falsely claims that the CSF collected from the first lumbar puncture was inadequate.

answers.content: "I sincerely apologize; the lab seems to have lost the specimens I obtained earlier."
answers.explanation_why: Although this response does disclose that the specimens were lost, it is inappropriate because it falsely blames the laboratory. Optimal error disclosure involves clearly admitting that an error has occurred and truthfully stating the course of events that led to the error.

answers.content: "There were just too many patients for us to keep track of today. I am so sorry, but I misplaced the specimens."
answers.explanation_why: Although this response does disclose that the physician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it makes an unprofessional excuse and implies that the error was unavoidable.

answers.content: "Based on your symptoms, I think you might have chronic meningitis."
answers.explanation_why: Although the patient's subacute development of nausea, vomiting, headache, and fevers is concerning for a diagnosis of chronic meningitis, this response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her sister 1 hour after she was found unconscious at home. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 5/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Urine toxicology screening is positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates. The patient's condition improves with supportive treatment, and she is admitted for psychiatric evaluation. Three days later, a physician colleague approaches the physician who treated the patient in the lobby of the hospital and states, “I just want to know what happened. I'm her neighbor and childhood friend, and I'm worried about her.” Which of the following responses by the treating physician is the most appropriate?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her sister 1 hour after she was found unconscious at home. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 5/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Urine toxicology screening is positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates. The patient's condition improves with supportive treatment, and she is admitted for psychiatric evaluation. Three days later, a physician colleague approaches the physician who treated the patient in the lobby of the hospital and states, “I just want to know what happened. I'm her neighbor and childhood friend, and I'm worried about her.” Which of the following responses by the treating physician is the most appropriate?
hint: The physician colleague is not directly involved in this patient's care.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of maintaining patient confidentiality in interactions with colleagues.

answers.content: "You can find the information in the electronic medical record."
answers.explanation_why: Viewing a patient's medical record for reasons unrelated to direct medical care violates the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act and is never appropriate.

answers.content: "Why don't you go ahead and ask her directly? She is currently in the psychiatric ward."
answers.explanation_why: Though this response encourages direct communication between the patient and her friend, it violates her privacy because it confirms that she is a patient at the hospital and discloses the nature of her medical care.

answers.content: "Her urine toxicology screening was positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates."
answers.explanation_why: Verbal or written consent from the patient is required before releasing information to any individuals who are not directly involved in her medical care, including the physician colleague. Sharing information at this time is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.

answers.content: "I'm not the right person to ask. Please ask her primary care physician."
answers.explanation_why: This response avoids the physician colleague's concern. Moreover, there is no indication that the primary care physician has permission to disclose information about the patient.

answers.content: "I understand your concern, but I am unable to provide information about this situation."
answers.explanation_why: This response demonstrates empathy for the physician colleague's concern and preserves the patient's privacy in accordance with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. Permission to disclose information can be obtained from the patient privately at a separate time. Alternatively, the patient can assume the responsibility of updating her friend with the information she chooses to share.

answers.content: "Let's go to my office to discuss her situation privately."
answers.explanation_why: Patient information should not be discussed in a public area (e.g., the hospital lobby). However, verbal or written consent from the patient is required before releasing information to any individuals who are not directly involved in her medical care, including the physician colleague. Sharing information at this time is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-month history of recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands. When he scrapes off the crusts, they reappear after a few days. The lesions are mildly pruritic and occasionally burn. He works as a landscaper. A photograph of his right hand is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-month history of recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands. When he scrapes off the crusts, they reappear after a few days. The lesions are mildly pruritic and occasionally burn. He works as a landscaper. A photograph of his right hand is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The hand is covered with light brown papules and rough, hyperkeratotic plaques. This condition is the result of years of exposure to sunlight without protection.
learning_objective: Recognize actinic keratosis.

answers.content: Actinic keratosis
answers.explanation_why:
Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that occurs on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, ears, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. The lesions typically grow back after they are scraped off. As a landscaper, this man has likely spent a lot of time working outdoors and has been frequently exposed to sun. Initially, actinic keratosis present as small, erythematous lesions with a central scale and a rough surface, giving them a sandpaper-like texture on palpation. Later, the lesions may grow and become erythematous and scaly, as seen in this patient. The risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma depends on the degree of epithelial dysplasia, but it is < 1% per year. Occasionally, hyperkeratosis may turn pre-existing actinic keratosis lesions into cutaneous horns.

Actinic keratosis is usually a clinical diagnosis, although in some cases a biopsy of the lesion may be necessary to distinguish it from squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment options include cryotherapy for isolated lesions, or 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod or photodynamic therapy in patients with multiple lesions, such as this man.

images.title: Actinic keratosis
images.description: The entire hairless portion of the scalp is covered with telangiectasia, light brown papules, and yellow-brownish, hyperkeratotic plaques.This appearance is typical of actinic keratoses.

answers.content: Seborrheic keratosis
answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor in individuals of advanced age and tends to affect the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and/or forearms. However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, the lesions are darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and 'stuck-on.'

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

answers.content: Basal cell carcinoma
answers.explanation_why: Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most common skin tumors and occur on areas of skin exposed to sun, especially the face. Given his occupation, this patient is at increased risk of developing BCCs. However, in contrast to this patient's lesions, which are erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques, BCCs manifest as pearly, indurated, and nodular lesions with a rolled border and a central depression (crater) with ulceration.

images.title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
images.description: An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

answers.content: Lichen planus
answers.explanation_why: Lichen planus manifests as symmetric, well-demarcated papules (not crusts) that have a polygonal shape and are usually severely pruritic. Although lichen planus commonly involves the hands, as in this patient, it predominantly affects the flexor surfaces rather than the extensor surfaces.

images.title: Lichen planus
images.description:
Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

answers.content: Keratoacanthoma
answers.explanation_why: While keratoacanthomas tend to occur on the face, neck, arms, or hands in individuals who have had an extensive history of sun exposure, such as this patient, they manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months. The patchy crusts on this patient's hands that have been recurring for 4 months are not consistent with keratoacanthoma.

images.title: Preauricular keratoacanthoma
images.description: An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

answers.content: Sporotrichosis
answers.explanation_why: Sporotrichosis results from infection with Sporothrix schenckii, which is commonly found on vegetation and garden soil and is typically transmitted by the prick of a thorn. While this patient's occupation as a landscaper puts him at risk of contracting this disease, sporotrichosis manifests initially as a papule at the site of inoculation, which often ulcerates. Subsequently, subcutaneous nodules and ulcers develop as the fungus spreads proximally along the lymphatic vessels (nodular ascending lymphangitis). This patient's recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands are not consistent with sporotrichosis.

images.title: Sporotrichosis (lymphocutaneous form)
images.description: Photograph of the left arm of a patientThere are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

images.title: Actinic keratosis
images.description: Right hand of an older patientMultiple scaly lesions on erythematous skin are visible.These lesions and their location (sun-exposed area) are typical of actinic keratosis.

question_text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of productive cough, weight loss, and intermittent fever. He recently returned from a 6-month medical deployment to Indonesia. He appears tired. Physical examination shows nontender, enlarged, palpable cervical lymph nodes. An x-ray of the chest shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy. A sputum smear shows acid-fast bacilli. A diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis is made from PCR testing of the sputum. The patient requests that the physician does not inform anyone of this diagnosis because he is worried about losing his job. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of productive cough, weight loss, and intermittent fever. He recently returned from a 6-month medical deployment to Indonesia. He appears tired. Physical examination shows nontender, enlarged, palpable cervical lymph nodes. An x-ray of the chest shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy. A sputum smear shows acid-fast bacilli. A diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis is made from PCR testing of the sputum. The patient requests that the physician does not inform anyone of this diagnosis because he is worried about losing his job. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: Physicians have an ethical and legal obligation to keep a patient's medical information confidential. There are, however, exceptions that relate to the imminent health and safety of the patient and/or the public.
learning_objective: Recognize exceptions to patient confidentiality for notifiable diseases.

answers.content: Inform the local public health department of the diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Although a physician is ethically and legally obligated to keep medical information confidential, there are exceptions to confidentiality, including notifiable diseases with public health implications, such as tuberculosis. This patient is newly diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and poses an infectious risk to the general public. Therefore, disclosure of the diagnosis and other pertinent information (e.g., drug susceptibility testing) to the public health department is necessary. Some local health departments will investigate close contacts for potential referral for evaluation and treatment.

answers.content: Request the patient's permission to discuss the diagnosis with an infectious disease specialist
answers.explanation_why: Requesting the patient's permission to discuss the diagnosis with an infectious disease specialist might increase the patient's confidence in the physician-patient relationship. Legally, however, a physician does not need a patient's consent to consult a specialist if the consultation directly relates to the patient's care. Furthermore, there are more time-sensitive steps that must be taken before consulting an infectious disease specialist.

answers.content: Assure the patient that his diagnosis will remain confidential
answers.explanation_why: This patient has asked the physician to keep the information confidential, which the physician is ethically and legally obligated to do, to an extent. However, given that this patient has been diagnosed with a condition (active pulmonary tuberculosis) that is immediately relevant to the health and welfare of other people, an exception to patient confidentiality is required. Therefore, providing assurance that the diagnosis will remain confidential is misleading.

answers.content: Confirm the diagnosis with a sputum culture
answers.explanation_why: The gold standard for diagnosis of tuberculosis is the isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from cultures on Löwenstein-Jensen agar. In practice, however, culture is not a practical means of establishing the diagnosis because growth can take up to 6 weeks. In this patient with a positive acid-fast stain and a positive PCR, the likelihood that he has tuberculosis is > 95%. A different step is more appropriate at this time in this patient.

answers.content: Notify all of the patient's household contacts of the diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Notifying all the patient's household contacts of the diagnosis without obtaining the patient's consent is a breach of confidentiality. This breach is both ethically and legally inappropriate. The physician should encourage the patient to inform close contacts (e.g., cohabitants, partners) of the diagnosis and try to obtain permission to inform these parties.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She previously had been adherent to her diet and medication but has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain since the last visit 6 months ago. She reports that she often misses doses of her metformin. Her hemoglobin A1c is 9.8%. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She previously had been adherent to her diet and medication but has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain since the last visit 6 months ago. She reports that she often misses doses of her metformin. Her hemoglobin A1c is 9.8%. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This patient has a markedly elevated hemoglobin A1c as a result of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Improving medication adherence is critical to preventing future complications.
learning_objective: Choose the initial action by the physician for a patient with poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes and medication nonadherence.

answers.content: Refer the patient to a dietician
answers.explanation_why: A referral to a registered dietician could be helpful in addressing this patient's obesity, and a low-carbohydrate, low-fat diet should be recommended to prevent cardiovascular disease and improve diabetic control. However, her poorly-controlled diabetes is most likely driven primarily by poor medication adherence.

answers.content: Schedule more frequent follow-up visits
answers.explanation_why: This patient's poor medication adherence is the most likely cause of her poorly-controlled diabetes, but the cause of her nonadherence is unclear at this point. Employing strategies that aim to strengthen the doctor-patient relationship and therapeutic alliance, such as scheduling frequent follow-up visits, and a patient-centered approach often improve patients' medication adherence. Frequent follow-up visits also enable closer monitoring of the patient's medication use. Other strategies to improve medication adherence include providing written instructions, optimizing the treatment plan (e.g., prescribing once-daily scheduled medications when possible), and using the teach-back method.

answers.content: Refer the patient to an endocrinologist
answers.explanation_why: Referring the patient to an endocrinologist is indicated if primary management strategies are unsuccessful or if the primary physician feels that managing this patient's condition and/or complications of her underlying disease exceed the level of his or her expertise. However, referral of this patient to an endocrinologist is not indicated at this time, since the elevated HbA1c is most likely due to poor medication adherence, which is well within the bounds of what can be expected of a primary physician.

answers.content: Add glyburide to the medication regimen
answers.explanation_why: The addition of glyburide, a sulfonylurea, is indicated if there is concern that monotherapy with metformin is inadequate for treatment of this patient's diabetes. However, this patient reports poor medication adherence; the addition of another agent is not indicated and may worsen adherence by complicating the medication regimen.

answers.content: Stop metformin and begin an insulin regimen
answers.explanation_why: Starting insulin should be considered if there is concern that metformin is inadequate for the treatment of this patient's diabetes. However, this patient reports poor medication adherence to metformin; control over her diabetes may improve after addressing this issue. Moreover, dosing for insulin therapy is more complicated than that for metformin therapy; inappropriate use of insulin can be dangerous due to the risk of inducing hypoglycemia.

question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
hint: The patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, and decreased DLCO raise suspicion for an interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, together with the upper lobe nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes, are characteristic of exposure to a substance classically associated with hard rock mining.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic silicosis, and recall its associated occupational exposure.

answers.content: Beryllium
answers.explanation_why: Berylliosis is typically seen in patients working in high-tech sectors, such as the nuclear and aerospace industries, where beryllium alloys are common. While berylliosis also affects the upper lobes and would present similarly to this patient, histological analysis is characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas and a reticular interstitial pattern on chest x-ray similar to that of sarcoidosis.

answers.content: Crystalline silica
answers.explanation_why:
This patient is suffering from chronic silicosis due to an occupational exposure to crystalline silica, as evidenced by the pathognomic biopsy findings that are consistent with a silicotic nodule. Radiographic abnormalities, such as diffuse ground glass or nodular opacities, can arise early in the disease (typically the upper lobes). However, overt symptoms can take decades of exposure to develop, which is consistent with this patient's advanced age.

Advanced silicosis patients are at particularly high risk for developing tuberculosis.

images.title: Silicosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspneaThere are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

answers.content: Moldy hay
answers.explanation_why: Exposure to thermophilic actinomyces spores in moldy hay can lead to a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, called Farmer's lung. This would also present with progressive dyspnea and chronic cough, but histology would instead reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells. Furthermore, chest x-ray would show ground-glass opacities with honeycombing, and in some cases, emphysema.

images.title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
images.description: H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

answers.content: Carbon dust
answers.explanation_why: Chronic exposure to carbon dust can result in Coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Similar to this patient's condition, black lung results in small nodular opacities on chest x-ray, specifically in the upper lung fields. Histologic analysis, however, would instead show deposition of dark pigment in the interstitial tissue and hilar lymph nodes due to carbon accumulation in alveolar macrophages.

answers.content: Asbestos fibers
answers.explanation_why: Exposure to asbestos fibers can lead to development of asbestosis later in life. While asbestosis also presents indolently with dyspnea and a chronic cough, the chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages.

question_text: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
content_preview: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
hint: If a patient lacks decision-making capacity, it is paramount that decisions be made based on what the patient would have wanted.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when addressing surrogate decision-making without a living will.

answers.content: Consult the hospital ethics committee
answers.explanation_why: Consulting the hospital ethics committee is appropriate if there is a complicated, unresolved ethical dilemma in which the stakeholders would benefit from the involvement of professionals (physicians, nurses, social workers, bioethicists) with advanced training in facilitating difficult decision-making. However, an ethics consult is more appropriate if there is a conflict between the four core bioethics principles of autonomy, beneficence, nonmaleficence, and justice. Disagreements between family members are routine in medical care, and the team should first attempt another course of action.

answers.content: Initiate total parenteral nutrition
answers.explanation_why: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is not indicated in this patient because she can still receive enteral nutrition (e.g., PEG).

answers.content: Encourage a family meeting
answers.explanation_why:
A family meeting with the patient's husband, sister, and members of the healthcare team could provide clarification as to what the patient would have desired had she been able to make the decision herself. Although the patient's sister and husband currently disagree, a discussion about the patient's own goals and values could encourage family agreement and facilitate better surrogate decision-making. If a resolution of the disagreement is not possible, the husband will most likely have the final say as his wife's next of kin.

The role of PEG placement in patients with dementia is controversial; studies have found no survival benefit or increase in quality of life in patients with advanced dementia who received PEG feeding compared with no tube feeding.

answers.content: Request a court-appointed guardian
answers.explanation_why: A request for a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions is typically made when there is no medical power of attorney or next-of-kin available to serve as surrogate decision maker. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved. Another approach would better facilitate reaching a decision in the best interests of the patient.

answers.content: Transfer to a physician specialized in hospice care
answers.explanation_why: Hospice care is not indicated here, as there is no suggestion that the patient is terminally ill and expected to live less than six months.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. His mother reports multiple instances over the past month when she walked into his room while he was masturbating. She is worried he may be going through some sort of “problem.” He is currently in 9^th grade. His mother says that he recently made his high school varsity wrestling team and does reasonably well in school. The patient had separation anxiety disorder at the age of 9 years, which resolved with cognitive behavioral therapy. On examination, he seems embarrassed and avoids making eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. His mother reports multiple instances over the past month when she walked into his room while he was masturbating. She is worried he may be going through some sort of “problem.” He is currently in 9th grade. His mother says that he recently made his high school varsity wrestling team and does reasonably well in school. The patient had separation anxiety disorder at the age of 9 years, which resolved with cognitive behavioral therapy. On examination, he seems embarrassed and avoids making eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: Masturbation is considered excessive if it causes significant distress and/or interferes with daily functioning.
learning_objective: Recognize normal sexual behaviors in adolescents and reassure concerned parents accordingly.

answers.content: Advise the patient to stop masturbating
answers.explanation_why: Advising to stop masturbating can be considered for patients whose masturbation is excessive and interferes with social or occupational functioning (e.g., skipping school to masturbate). This adolescent does not seem to be affected in his ability to carry out daily activities and is succeeding academically.

answers.content: Measure serum testosterone level
answers.explanation_why: Measuring serum testosterone levels should be considered in case of delayed puberty, which the patient shows no features of. Abnormal levels of testosterone are unlikely to manifest with excessive masturbation.

answers.content: Refer the patient for behavioral therapy
answers.explanation_why: Behavioral therapy can be used to treat sexual dysfunction disorders (e.g., male hypoactive sexual desire disorder, female sexual arousal disorder, genito-pelvic pain disorder). However, masturbation that does not interfere with daily functioning is not considered a sexual dysfunction disorder and does not require behavioral therapy.

answers.content: Reassure the mother
answers.explanation_why: Masturbation is a normal activity in individuals of all ages and is only considered abnormal if it becomes disruptive and/or impairs social or occupational functioning (e.g., skipping school to masturbate). This patient has not been affected in his ability to carry out daily activities and is succeeding academically. Therefore, masturbation should not be discouraged and the patient's mother should be reassured and counseled appropriately.

answers.content: Prescribe sertraline
answers.explanation_why: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., sertraline) are indicated in patients with psychiatric disorders such as depression or generalized anxiety disorder. This patient has no features that suggest a psychiatric illness.

answers.content: Refer the patient for psychoanalytic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Psychoanalytic therapy may be useful in the treatment of certain sexual disorders, including difficulty sustaining healthy sexual relationships. However, masturbation that does not interfere with daily functioning is not considered a sexual dysfunction disorder and does not require psychoanalysis.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no history of serious illness. He has been married to his wife for 5 years. They are sexually active and use condoms inconsistently. After the examination, the patient mentions he had an affair with a female partner several months ago. He is concerned he may have contracted a sexually transmitted infection and requests testing. One week later, the patient tests positive on a fourth-generation HIV antibody and antigen test and an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. The patient is counseled on the test results. He requests that his results not be disclosed to anyone including his wife because he is afraid she will leave him. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step by the physician?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no history of serious illness. He has been married to his wife for 5 years. They are sexually active and use condoms inconsistently. After the examination, the patient mentions he had an affair with a female partner several months ago. He is concerned he may have contracted a sexually transmitted infection and requests testing. One week later, the patient tests positive on a fourth-generation HIV antibody and antigen test and an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. The patient is counseled on the test results. He requests that his results not be disclosed to anyone including his wife because he is afraid she will leave him. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step by the physician?
hint: Although medical information is confidential, there are exemptions for certain transmissible infectious diseases, such as HIV and other STIs (e.g., syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, chancroid).
learning_objective: Recognize the legal requirement to report certain infectious diseases, like HIV, to public health authorities.

answers.content: Report the results to the local health department
answers.explanation_why: Physicians are required by law to report certain transmissible infectious diseases (e.g., HIV) to public health authorities (typically the local and/or state health department), which then reports anonymized information to the CDC. During testing, patients should be informed that HIV is a notifiable disease. Patients diagnosed with HIV should be encouraged to disclose their status to their sexual and/or needle-sharing partners. Many states also have partner notification laws that legally require disclosure of HIV status to exposed third parties, either by the patient, the health department, or the physician. Public health officials provide partner notification services for locating and notifying third parties if the patient declines to do so. Regardless of which method is used, exposed partners should be provided with resources for counseling, testing, and treatment.

answers.content: Inform the patient that you will not tell his wife but have to tell her physician
answers.explanation_why: Sharing the patient's test results with another physician who is not directly involved in their care is inappropriate because it breaches patient confidentiality.

answers.content: Schedule a group meeting with the patient and his wife to disclose the results
answers.explanation_why: Although physicians can assist patients in disclosing their HIV status, this patient is reluctant to notify his wife. Therefore, scheduling a group meeting is unlikely to be productive. Furthermore, because a physician's right to disclose a patient's HIV status varies by state, notifying the spouse could breach patient confidentiality laws. If a patient declines to disclose their HIV status to their partners, the physician should use confidential partner notification services, which are typically provided by public health authorities.

answers.content: Ask the patient to inform the CDC about his diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Certain infectious diseases, such as HIV, must be reported to public health authorities (e.g., CDC) to prevent or control the spread of infection. However, physicians and/or laboratories rather than patients are responsible for reporting HIV infections. Moreover, the CDC only receives anonymized information.

answers.content: Tell the patient that you will have to inform his wife if he does not tell her by the end of the week
answers.explanation_why: Patients diagnosed with HIV should be encouraged to disclose their HIV status to their sexual and/or needle-sharing partners. In some states, physicians also have the right to directly inform the partner at risk. However, threatening or coercing patients causes distrust and can negatively affect treatment (e.g., the patient fails to return for follow-up).
