question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of unexplained weight loss over the past 8 months. During the examination, he tells the physician that he has been having marital issues with his wife. He filed for bankruptcy 2 months ago for a business he had owned with his brother until his brother died of skin cancer a year ago. He has tried to hide his financial issues from his wife and explains that he is feeling increasingly desperate and no longer “sees the light at the end of the tunnel.” He worries about finances and what would happen if he developed cancer like his brother, and then cannot fall asleep. In the morning, he feels tired and finds it hard to start the day. The patient says the symptoms began a few months after his brother's death and then, “Everything started to fall apart. I can't concentrate, my wife will probably leave me soon, and now I have lost the business.” Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of unexplained weight loss over the past 8 months. During the examination, he tells the physician that he has been having marital issues with his wife. He filed for bankruptcy 2 months ago for a business he had owned with his brother until his brother died of skin cancer a year ago. He has tried to hide his financial issues from his wife and explains that he is feeling increasingly desperate and no longer “sees the light at the end of the tunnel.” He worries about finances and what would happen if he developed cancer like his brother, and then cannot fall asleep. In the morning, he feels tired and finds it hard to start the day. The patient says the symptoms began a few months after his brother's death and then, “Everything started to fall apart. I can't concentrate, my wife will probably leave me soon, and now I have lost the business.” Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
hint: This patient, who presents with a depressed mood, sleep disturbance, fatigue, diminished concentration, and weight loss over a period > 2 weeks, is experiencing a major depressive episode.
learning_objective: Recognize symptoms of a major depressive episode and assess for suicidal ideation.

answers.content: "I cannot imagine how hard this must be for you. You say you no longer see the light at the end of the tunnel. Are you having thoughts of suicide?"
answers.explanation_why: Through this reaction, the physician shows empathy and specifically asks about suicidal ideation. Assessing a patient's suicide risk is the most important diagnostic step for any depressed individual. If the patient confirms that he is having suicidal ideation, the physician should also ask the patient if he has thought of a means of suicide (suicidal plan), assess the degree to which he intends to put the plan into action (suicidal intent), and evaluate whether additional risk factors for suicide completion are present (e.g., possession of a firearm, personal and family history of prior suicide attempts). If the patient is suicidal, they should be admitted to the hospital. Treatment of a major depressive episode often requires a combination of antidepressants, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

answers.content: "Considering what you have been going through, it is absolutely normal to feel that way. You will see that things will become easier for you over time!"
answers.explanation_why: Through this reaction, the physician minimizes the patient's symptoms. Although it could be normal for the patient to occasionally have some of his symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, decreased sleep, decreased concentration) as a part of grief, it is not normal to have them on a persistent basis or have unexplained weight loss over 8 months. Moreover, by saying, “You will see that things will become easier for you over time!" the physician is making promises that cannot be guaranteed.

answers.content: "It sounds like you are depressed, but before we begin treatment for depression, I would like to evaluate you for any underlying conditions that may be causing your mood changes."
answers.explanation_why: Depression can be caused by organic conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, CNS neoplasm, Parkinson disease), and it is necessary to evaluate patients with features of depression for organic disease. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.

answers.content: "This is obviously a very difficult time for you and it would be normal to turn to certain substances when you are feeling this way. Would you be willing to provide a urine sample for testing?"
answers.explanation_why: Depression can be caused by a substance use disorder, and it is necessary to evaluate any patient with features of depression for a substance use disorder. However, it would be inappropriate to perform a urine toxicology screen before first directly asking the patient about substance use and examining the patient for signs of a substance use disorder.

answers.content: "Losing your brother must have been extremely hard for you. Would you be willing to speak with a grief counselor?"
answers.explanation_why: A referral to a grief counselor is appropriate for the management of grief, which is caused by the death of a loved one and can present with symptoms such as a depressed mood, disturbed sleep, and decreased concentration, as seen here. However, the symptoms of grief tend to occur in waves (grief pangs), decrease over time, and are not associated with functional impairment or feelings of desperation. This patient's presentation is consistent with a major depressive episode and cannot be treated by grief counseling alone. Moreover, even in patients with grief, it is important to first ask a specific question in order to differentiate normal from pathological grief.

answers.content: "After the death of your brother, it is even more important to stay close to your family. What do you think about starting to attend family therapy with your wife?"
answers.explanation_why: The patient said that he has been having marital issues with his wife, so seeing a family therapist with his wife could be beneficial. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a follow-up evaluation of a spinal lesion identified during surveillance imaging. One year ago, he had tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He undergoes a CT-guided needle biopsy of the spinal lesion and is awaiting the pathology result. A medical student, who is part of the team involved in the patient's care, sees the patient in the hospital cafeteria. The student has just reviewed the patient's spinal biopsy result, which is consistent with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of oropharyngeal origin. The patient approaches the student in the cafeteria and asks if the biopsy result has come back. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a follow-up evaluation of a spinal lesion identified during surveillance imaging. One year ago, he had tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He undergoes a CT-guided needle biopsy of the spinal lesion and is awaiting the pathology result. A medical student, who is part of the team involved in the patient's care, sees the patient in the hospital cafeteria. The student has just reviewed the patient's spinal biopsy result, which is consistent with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of oropharyngeal origin. The patient approaches the student in the cafeteria and asks if the biopsy result has come back. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
hint: The student should act in the best interest of the patient while also being honest with him.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate protocol for disclosing patient information as a medical student.

answers.content: "I believe the biopsy showed cancer, but I have to review the result with the rest of the team to confirm."
answers.explanation_why: Although the student is acknowledging the need to discuss with the team, they should not disclose the result to the patient before consulting with the senior team members. In addition, the patient's medical information should not be shared in a public space such as the hospital cafeteria. Finally, this can cause psychological harm to the patient as he will likely be worried the whole time while waiting for the confirmation of the results.

answers.content: "Unfortunately, the biopsy is consistent with cancer and your prognosis is poor since it indicates metastasis."
answers.explanation_why: Although the student already knows the result of the biopsy and it is important to be honest with the patient, it is unlikely that the student can provide the most accurate and complete information about the topic. Therefore, it would not be appropriate for the student to disclose the information to the patient in this situation. Moreover, medical information should not be disclosed in public spaces such as the hospital cafeteria.

answers.content: "The result is back but I need to discuss it with the team before I can give you accurate information."
answers.explanation_why: Medical students are often confronted with situations in which patients ask them to disclose diagnostic workup, treatment options, or information on prognosis. The result of the biopsy should not be disclosed until the student is able to discuss it with senior members of the team, because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and detailed information about complex topics. The student must also be honest with the patient, acknowledging that the information requested is available and explaining why its disclosure is being withheld. Finally, the cafeteria is not an appropriate environment to deliver clinical information to the patient. Clinical information should be disclosed in an environment in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured.

answers.content: "I do not know if the biopsy result is back but I will get back to you."
answers.explanation_why: The student must be honest with the patient, and they already know the result of the patient's biopsy. Lying to the patient violates the principle of honesty.

answers.content: "Let's go back to your room so it's more private and I will go over the result with you."
answers.explanation_why: When disclosing a patient's medical information, one should look for an appropriate environment to deliver it to the patient, in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured. However, it is not appropriate for the student to disclose the results at this time because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and complete information about complex topics.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV_1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
hint: This patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, digital clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, and restrictive pattern of lung disease on spirometry (normal to increased FEV_1:FVC ratio, decreased VC) raises concern for interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, which indicate carbon-laden macrophages, and imaging findings are characteristic of exposure to a noxious agent in this field of work.
learning_objective: Recognize black lung disease, and recall the risk factor for this pneumoconiosis.

answers.content: Roofing
answers.explanation_why: Construction workers (e.g., plumbing, roofing, insulation), firefighters wearing heat-resistant clothing, and shipbuilders with cumulative exposure to asbestos are at risk for asbestosis. While patients with asbestosis present with dyspnea and chronic cough, chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages. Carbon-laden macrophages are not an expected biopsy finding in asbestosis.

answers.content: Sandblasting
answers.explanation_why: Workers exposed to silica dust (e.g., in sandblasting, mining, casting metals) are at risk for silicosis, which usually manifests with a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. Chest x-ray findings in silicosis also typically appear on the upper lobes more than the lower lobes with hilar eggshell calcifications and nodular opacities. However, lung biopsy findings typically show silicotic nodules, which are composed of collagen fibers surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes, and, possibly, intra- or extracellular birefringent silica particles. Carbon-laden macrophages are not a common biopsy finding in silicosis.

answers.content: Uranium processing
answers.explanation_why: Workers in uranium processing (especially mining) can be exposed to radon gas, a radioactive byproduct of uranium decay, which increases the risk of lung cancer. Chest x-ray findings in lung cancer typically show a solitary nodule, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, uranium workers can be exposed to dusts, including silica, which increases the risk for silicosis. In this condition, chest x-ray characteristically shows interstitial nodular opacities in the upper lobes similar to the findings in this patient. However, lung biopsy in silicosis typically shows silicotic nodules, which do not include carbon-laden macrophages.

answers.content: Aerospace manufacturing
answers.explanation_why: Workers in aerospace manufacturing are often exposed to beryllium alloys, which can cause berylliosis following high-grade exposure. Although berylliosis can manifest with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, lung biopsy typically reveals noncaseating granulomas similar to those seen in sarcoidosis rather than carbon-laden macrophages. Additionally, while opacities are also typically seen more in the upper lobes than the lower lobes of the lung, chest x-ray would reveal more of a reticular interstitial pattern.

answers.content: Farming
answers.explanation_why: Farmers are chronically exposed to organic dust (e.g., from molds, animal proteins) and are at risk for chronic hypersensitivity pneumonia, which is characterized by slowly progressive dyspnea, bilateral crackles, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. However, chest x-ray typically shows ground-glass opacities with honeycombing (fibrotic changes), and lung biopsy is likely to reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells rather than carbon-laden macrophages.

answers.content: Coal mining
answers.explanation_why:
Coal miners are at increased risk of coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also called black lung disease, a more severe form of anthracosis caused by chronic occupational exposure to large amounts of carbon dust. Patients with coal workers' pneumoconiosis present with symptoms of chronic bronchitis, which can progress to severe dyspnea indicating massive pulmonary fibrosis. Inhaled carbon particles accumulate in alveolar macrophages and induce inflammation and fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. Chest x-ray can reveal small, nodular, potentially coalescing opacities in the upper lung lobes. Finally, lung biopsy characteristically shows deposition of dark pigment in macrophages, interstitial tissue, and hilar lymph nodes.

Caplan syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis, including coal workers' pneumoconiosis, that manifests with rheumatoid arthritis. Although this patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, he does not have Caplan syndrome. If he were to develop this complication, he would likely present with concurrent symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, more rapidly progressive shortness of breath, chest x-ray findings of more peripheral and/or larger nodules, and biopsy findings similar to those seen in rheumatoid nodules (i.e., central fibrinoid necrosis with histiocytes and surrounding epithelial cells).

images.title: Anthracotic pigment in lung in coal worker's pneumoconiosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain, low magnification)Accumulations of carbon particles (anthracotic pigment) can be seen in the lung tissue. Some of the pigment can be found in pigment-laden macrophages. Also, collagenous fibrosis is predominant throughout the lung tissue.This appearance is diagnostic of pneumoconiosis (e.g., coal workers' pneumoconiosis).

question_text: A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting, but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting, but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation?
hint: In the absence of an oral or written advance directive for a deceased individual, a surrogate decision-maker (SDM) should be designated to act in their best interest. An SDM may be designated by a patient prior to loss of capacity (e.g., durable medical power of attorney), legally appointed (a court-appointed guardian), or appointed via default sequence among the next of kin.
learning_objective: Recognize the hierarchy of surrogate decision-makers in organ donation when advance directives are absent.

answers.content: Encourage another family meeting with a social worker
answers.explanation_why: If there is a disagreement between the next of kin on the most appropriate course of action, it is appropriate for the physician to first encourage a meeting between disagreeing family members with the aim of reaching an agreement about what the deceased would have desired. However, such a meeting has already been arranged, and there are no grounds to assume that a second meeting with a social worker would provide further clarification. Most states generally establish a clear hierarchy for who would be assigned as the SDM among the next of kin.

answers.content: Initiate organ procurement procedures
answers.explanation_why: It would be appropriate to proceed with the organ procurement process if the parents had consented to organ donation because parents are generally considered the highest priority SDMs after spouses. In this scenario, a different action is appropriate in most states.

answers.content: Request a court-appointed guardian
answers.explanation_why: It is appropriate to request a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions when there is no medical power of attorney or next of kin available to serve as the SDM. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved, some of whom qualify to be SDMs, so it would not be necessary to request a court-appointed guardian.

answers.content: Do not proceed with organ donation
answers.explanation_why: If the patient lacks decision-making capacity or is deceased and does not have advance directives, a self-appointed SDM, or court-appointed SDM, the next of kin becomes their SDM. Most states have established a hierarchy to assign a next of kin as the SDM, although the order may vary from state to state. Spouses are most often listed first, followed by adult children, parents, adult siblings, and close friends. Fiancés and nonlegal partners are not considered spouses in most states, and adulthood is typically defined as 18 years of age. In this case, the patient's parents, who are not in favor of organ donation, would serve as this patient's representatives. The organ donation process should therefore be stopped.

answers.content: Request the patient’s son to intercede and make a decision
answers.explanation_why: Although mature or emancipated minors can, in some states, under rare circumstances, be appointed as SDMs, individuals under 18 years of age are generally considered legally incompetent to make medical decisions. This patient's son is 17 years of age and not considered a mature or emancipated minor, so another person would be designated as the SDM.

question_text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and underwent a total hysterectomy for a severe postpartum hemorrhage 4 years ago. The results of her last high-risk HPV/Pap smear cotest from 5 years ago were negative. Current medications include propranolol, warfarin, and a vitamin supplement. She is married and has two children. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 126/72 mm Hg; her BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends stopping high-risk HPV testing and Pap smears in this patient. Which of the following considerations best explains the physician's recommendation?
content_preview: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and underwent a total hysterectomy for a severe postpartum hemorrhage 4 years ago. The results of her last high-risk HPV/Pap smear cotest from 5 years ago were negative. Current medications include propranolol, warfarin, and a vitamin supplement. She is married and has two children. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 126/72 mm Hg; her BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician recommends stopping high-risk HPV testing and Pap smears in this patient. Which of the following considerations best explains the physician's recommendation?
hint: Another application of this system-based concept is the recommendation to stop all cancer screening protocols in patients with end-stage kidney disease.
learning_objective: Recognize the concept of resource stewardship in healthcare.

answers.content: Therapeutic privilege
answers.explanation_why: Therapeutic privilege refers to a situation in which a physician withholds relevant health information from the patient if disclosure may cause severe psychological harm to the patient. In this case, therapeutic privilege does not apply because the physician did not withhold any information from the patient.

answers.content: Resource stewardship
answers.explanation_why: Resource stewardship refers to the concept of managing the distribution of limited health care resources in order to avoid unnecessary testing and procedures. This means that more resources will be directed to the individuals who need them the most and patients will be spared from undergoing unnecessary procedures that may be more harmful than beneficial. For example, this patient, who underwent a total hysterectomy, is no longer at risk for cervical cancer and therefore does not require further Pap smears or screening for human papillomavirus. One way of improving resource stewardship is the lean process improvement method, in which factors that use time, energy, and resources but do not improve patient outcomes (also referred to as “waste”) are continuously identified and eliminated.

answers.content: Shared decision-making
answers.explanation_why: Shared decision-making is a communication principle in which patients and physicians decide on the best treatment option together. In this case, the physician made a recommendation without first consulting with the patient, which means this was not a shared decision-making process.

answers.content: Healthcare ergonomics
answers.explanation_why: Healthcare ergonomics refers to the concept of creating a work environment that provides optimal working conditions for health care workers, which reduces injuries, ensures safety, and optimizes efficiency. This concept can be applied to the design of medical equipment, new medical technologies, and optimizing processes, but it does not apply to this scenario.

answers.content: Medication reconciliation
answers.explanation_why: Medication reconciliation is the process of a physician comparing the patient's current prescribed medications to the ones actually taken in order to avoid medication errors (e.g., drug interactions, dosing errors, duplications, omissions). The physician's recommendation to stop Pap smears and HPV testing does not count as medical reconciliation.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a routine health examination. According to the patient's mother, the boy has been more withdrawn lately and has also lost some weight, which she finds “suspicious.” Their family moved from a different state 6 months ago. The boy has some difficulty making friends at the new school but has good academic performance. He enjoys playing drums and has a good appetite. The patient says he tried beer before but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are normal. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. The physician reassures the parents that their son is experiencing a normal stress reaction. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother asks if she could talk to the physician in private. When left alone with the physician, the mother says: “I think my son is lying about the drug use. Could you please run a drug test on him but tell him it is just a routine laboratory test?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a routine health examination. According to the patient's mother, the boy has been more withdrawn lately and has also lost some weight, which she finds “suspicious.” Their family moved from a different state 6 months ago. The boy has some difficulty making friends at the new school but has good academic performance. He enjoys playing drums and has a good appetite. The patient says he tried beer before but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are normal. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. The physician reassures the parents that their son is experiencing a normal stress reaction. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother asks if she could talk to the physician in private. When left alone with the physician, the mother says: “I think my son is lying about the drug use. Could you please run a drug test on him but tell him it is just a routine laboratory test?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: Regardless of the medical issue, it is preferable for the physician to gain the minor's approval before starting medical care.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to parental requests for confidential testing on a minor.

answers.content: "We can perform this test only if you as a parent sign a liability waiver."
answers.explanation_why: There is no liability waiver applicable for the scenario presented in this case.

answers.content: "I understand your concern and will schedule the test for our next appointment."
answers.explanation_why: Empathetic communication with a patient and/or their family promotes a trusting relationship, which can ultimately improve the care of the patient. However, physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth, and deceiving the patient would be inappropriate.

answers.content: "I do not think your son is using drugs, since his examination showed no abnormalities."
answers.explanation_why: This response is prematurely dismissive of the parent's concerns and does not allow for investigation of the underlying reason for her concerns. Moreover, a normal physical and mental examination cannot rule out substance use disorders.

answers.content: "I cannot lie to your son about the nature of the test. Why do you think your son is lying about the drug use?"
answers.explanation_why: Physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth. Lying to a patient will likely damage the physician-patient relationship and possibly impede future care. Moreover, parental consent for medical care of an unemancipated minor is not required in matters of sex (e.g., contraception, pregnancy care except for abortion in most states, STIs) or addiction care; in these instances, minors can receive care without their parent's knowledge or consent. This patient's physical and mental examinations provide no evidence of compromised decision-making capacity, indicating that he is able to provide informed consent for his own medical care. In the case presented here, the physician should acknowledge the mother's concerns, investigate the underlying reasons for her request by asking open-ended questions, and explain the limitations of drug testing (e.g., false positives, false negatives). If the physician concludes that a drug screening test is appropriate, the next step would be to meet privately with the patient and seek his consent. Minors should also be encouraged to discuss their issues with their parents.

answers.content: "I could do this, but I think it would be better if you discussed your concerns with your son first."
answers.explanation_why: Encouraging parents to openly discuss their concerns with their children (and vice versa) is always recommended. However, physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth, and deceiving the patient would be inappropriate.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat. He has not had a cough. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. He has no known allergies. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (108 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m^2. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F). Examination of the oral cavity discloses erythema and edema of the oropharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococci is positive. The physician prescribes penicillin V oral tablets. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to write the prescription?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat. He has not had a cough. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. He has no known allergies. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (108 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F). Examination of the oral cavity discloses erythema and edema of the oropharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococci is positive. The physician prescribes penicillin V oral tablets. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to write the prescription?
hint: Physicians should prescribe medications as precisely and simply as possible in order to prevent errors and maximize patient safety.
learning_objective: Recognize how to write a prescription clearly and accurately.

answers.content: Penicillin V, 500 mg, orally, twice a day, for 10 days
answers.explanation_why:
This prescription is written in precise, simple, and common language and is, therefore, least likely to result in a medication error. First, the drug is named specifically (“Penicillin V”). Second, the dosage (“500 mg”) describes the drug strength in clearly defined units and does not contain trailing zeros. Third, the route (“orally”), frequency (“twice a day”), and duration (“for 10 days”) of administration are all written in plain English; Latin, abbreviations, and acronyms should be avoided because they can be misinterpreted.

In addition, it is recommended to indicate the reason for the medication on the prescription (e.g., “Streptococcal pharyngitis”), as this introduces an additional safety checkpoint and opportunity for counseling for pharmacists and collaborating providers, and reminds the patient of the drug's purpose. Other instructions typically provided on prescriptions include the number of medication units to be dispensed and the number of refills permitted before the patient's next follow-up.

answers.content: Pen-V, 500.00 mg, orally, twice a day, as directed
answers.explanation_why: In general, it is recommended to use generic (e.g., “Penicillin V”) rather than commercial drug names (e.g., “Pen-V”) on prescriptions to avoid conflicts of interest and decrease the risk of confusing similar-sounding medications. Furthermore, the use of vague statements such as “as directed” should be avoided. The use of trailing zeros as in “500.00 mg” should be avoided because the dosage can be easily misread (e.g., 50000 mg), which can result in serious adverse events.

answers.content: Penicillin, 500 mg, PO, BID, for 10 days
answers.explanation_why: Drugs should be identified as specifically as possible; this prescription does not specify which type of penicillin is being prescribed. Furthermore, the use of Latin and acronyms such as “PO” (per os, which means by mouth) or “BID” (bis in die, which means twice a day) should be avoided.

answers.content: Penicillin V, 25 mg/kg, orally, twice a day, as directed
answers.explanation_why: Although pediatric dosages can be written using the units “mg/kg,” the use of vague statements such as “as directed” should be avoided.

answers.content: Penicillin V, 25.0 mg/kg, orally, b.d.s., for 10 days
answers.explanation_why: The use of trailing zeros as in “25.0 mg/kg” should be avoided because the dosage can be easily misread (e.g., 250 mg/kg), which can result in serious adverse events. Moreover, the use of Latin and acronyms such as “b.d.s” (bis die sumendum, which means twice a day) is discouraged.

question_text: A 74-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 5-week history of fever, fatigue, and cough with purulent sputum. He has not seen a doctor in 5 years. He appears thin. Chest x-ray shows a patchy infiltrate in the left lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum reveals acid-fast bacilli. Polymerase chain reaction confirms the diagnosis of respiratory tuberculosis and the patient is placed in an airborne infection isolation room. A nurse and a medical student enter the patient's room to insert a urinary catheter. While preparing to insert the catheter, the student notices that the nurse has put on nonsterile gloves. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the medical student?
content_preview: A 74-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 5-week history of fever, fatigue, and cough with purulent sputum. He has not seen a doctor in 5 years. He appears thin. Chest x-ray shows a patchy infiltrate in the left lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum reveals acid-fast bacilli. Polymerase chain reaction confirms the diagnosis of respiratory tuberculosis and the patient is placed in an airborne infection isolation room. A nurse and a medical student enter the patient's room to insert a urinary catheter. While preparing to insert the catheter, the student notices that the nurse has put on nonsterile gloves. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the medical student?
hint: Urinary catheter insertion is an aseptic procedure. Sterile technique, including wearing sterile gloves, should be maintained. Any break in the sterile field jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize and address breaches in sterile technique to ensure patient safety.

answers.content: "I believe you accidentally put on the wrong gloves."
answers.explanation_why: Whenever a person witnesses a medical error, they should directly inform the health care provider who committed the error. This should be done politely and without regard for workplace hierarchy, interpersonal relationships, or the potential of a career setback. A witness who fails to act is also culpable for the consequences of the error. Early medical error reporting can offer a chance for rectification (e.g., replacing nonsterile gloves with sterile gloves) and prevent a near miss (e.g., break of sterile technique) from becoming an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Patient safety (nonmaleficence) is the foremost priority; a safety culture fosters the reporting of both active errors (as seen here) and latent errors.

answers.content: “I suggest we perform a root cause analysis to make sure this error does not happen again.”
answers.explanation_why: Analysis of medical errors (e.g., root cause analysis) is in line with good safety culture and necessary to prevent future errors. However, a root cause analysis is performed after a procedure has been completed. Another reaction is more appropriate at this point in time.

answers.content: “I am really sorry, but I have to report your mistake to the head nurse to ensure transparent communication.”
answers.explanation_why: It is necessary to report of medical errors (e.g., through an incident reporting system), and doing so is in line with good safety culture. However, reporting the error to the head nurse at this step in the procedure delays the possibility of rectifying the error and increases the risk that a near miss (e.g., break in sterile technique) becomes an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the person who committed the error to report it. It would be more appropriate for the student to give the nurse the chance to self report the error at a later time.

answers.content: “Let’s go over everything again to make sure we did not forget something before we insert the catheter."
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not directly address the problem that sterile technique has not been followed, which may convey the assumption that the procedure has not been compromised. Whenever a medical error is witnessed, the witness of the error should speak up. Addressing the error immediately makes rectification possible.

answers.content: “Do you need any help with the insertion of the catheter?”
answers.explanation_why: Collaboration across teams is necessary, and it is generally appropriate for the student to offer to help the nurse. However, urinary catheter insertion should be performed using sterile technique, which includes wearing sterile gloves. This nurse just put on nonsterile gloves. Any break in sterile technique jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error. Another reaction is more appropriate at this stage of the procedure.

question_text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician?
content_preview: An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician?
hint: This patient's physical examination findings (abnormal finger-to-nose test indicating a cerebellar condition, eye blinking as a response to a sudden hand wave indicating intact visual pathway) do not correlate with his presenting symptom (blurry vision) and additional examination findings (poor visual acuity indicating defective visual pathway). In combination with his request for a letter excusing him from military training, this should raise concern for malingering.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of malingering, and choose the appropriate management strategy.

answers.content: Schedule regular follow-up meetings
answers.explanation_why: Meeting on a regular basis in order to build a collaborative patient-physician relationship is important for patients with somatic symptom disorder, a mental disorder in which patients experience various somatic symptoms resulting in significant distress. However, this patient's presentation suggests that he is malingering, which is not a psychiatric disorder, but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money). It would be inappropriate to schedule follow-up meetings without addressing his malingering behavior.

answers.content: Initiate a discussion about the patient's recent enlistment to the military
answers.explanation_why: Initiating a discussion about his recent enlistment to the military in a calm, distant, yet empathetic manner gives the patient the opportunity to be honest without becoming uncomfortable and possibly compromising the patient-physician relationship. Malingering individuals are often noncompliant and insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Unnecessary referrals should be avoided because they perpetuate malingering, which is a behavior and not a psychiatric disorder.

answers.content: Provide the patient with an exemption letter for military service
answers.explanation_why: Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and writing an exemption letter for military training would reward and perpetuate his malingering behavior.

answers.content: Refer the patient to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and referring him to an ophthalmologist would be indicated if a medical condition of the visual pathway was suspected. No medical conditions of the visual pathway are suspected in this patient, so this action would not be appropriate.

answers.content: Educate the patient about his diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Patient education is the first-line treatment for functional neurological symptom disorder, a mental disorder that can manifest with vision loss without evidence of a defective visual pathway. This patient is most likely malingering, which is not a psychiatric diagnosis but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money), so patient education would not be appropriate.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: The failure to provide full disclosure in a timely manner constitutes a medical error. The right action in this scenario is grounded in the principles of professional respect and a systems-based approach toward medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of addressing medical errors through professional communication, and choose the appropriate steps to disclose such errors to the patient.

answers.content: Request that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: A medical error should be promptly disclosed to the patient, regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm. The clinician should explain the error and any consequences and allow time for further discussion and questions. Requesting that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test is inappropriate because it would unnecessarily delay patient notification.

answers.content: Speak to the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why:
When a clinician suspects a medical error, they must speak privately and nonjudgmentally with the responsible colleague to determine whether an error occurred and why (e.g., misunderstanding or laboratory error). To help reduce the risk of future errors, the clinician should encourage their colleague to report the incident using standard protocol. Most medical errors are caused by failures in health care systems, and incident reporting can contribute to the identification and improvement of systemic issues. If there is no longer a patient-physician relationship with the colleague, the clinician must comply with HIPAA regulations by initially obtaining the patient’s permission to contact the physician.

Additionally, the clinician should inform the patient of the previous test result and discuss its implications, ensuring transparency and prioritizing care. In this scenario, the patient does not have HIV, and no further testing is needed.

answers.content: Report the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test to the state medical board
answers.explanation_why: The physician should report the colleague directly to the state medical board if the colleague is suspected of committing gross misconduct (e.g., billing fraud, bullying, sexual harassment). At this point, this action is inappropriate.

answers.content: Disclose to the patient that a colleague forgot to follow up on the results of the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: It is inappropriate to make assumptions about a colleague's actions. Without investigating, the physician cannot definitively know the reason for the error (e.g., lack of follow-up or laboratory error). A different action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Do not inform the patient since the error did not cause harm
answers.explanation_why: Clinicians must inform patients about a medical error regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm.

question_text: A 46-year-old man who is a prisoner comes to the county jail urgent care clinic because of a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, and right-sided chest pain. During this time, he also has had shortness of breath and a 6 kg (13 lb) weight loss. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia but his symptoms did not improve. He worked as a construction worker for 15 years. He has HIV infection and hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and antiretroviral therapy. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally; there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Chest x-ray shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy, a fibrous, cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe, and right-sided pleural effusion. CD4 count is 600/mm^3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man who is a prisoner comes to the county jail urgent care clinic because of a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, and right-sided chest pain. During this time, he also has had shortness of breath and a 6 kg (13 lb) weight loss. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia but his symptoms did not improve. He worked as a construction worker for 15 years. He has HIV infection and hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and antiretroviral therapy. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally; there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Chest x-ray shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy, a fibrous, cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe, and right-sided pleural effusion. CD4 count is 600/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Analysis of the pleural fluid would show lymphocyte-predominant leukocytosis and high levels of protein, lactate dehydrogenase, and adenosine deaminase.
learning_objective: Recognize primary tuberculosis in an HIV-positive patient.

answers.content: Hodgkin lymphoma
answers.explanation_why: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can manifest with B symptoms as well as hilar lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion on chest x-ray, all of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, mediastinal masses, which cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough, are a common feature of HL. However, this patient's chest x-ray shows no signs of a mediastinal mass; his cavitary lesion is not consistent with HL. Moreover, patients with HL typically have a dry rather than productive cough and often present with painless lymphadenopathy, especially in the cervical nodes, which is not seen here.

images.title: Anterior mediastinal mass in Hodgkin lymphoma
images.description: X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphomaThe PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).Li: liver; LV: left ventricle

answers.content: Pulmonary sarcoidosis
answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary sarcoidosis can manifest with coughing, dyspnea, chest pain, and constitutional symptoms. However, pulmonary sarcoidosis usually manifests with a dry rather than productive cough, and a chest x-ray would show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticular or ground-glass opacities, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.

images.title: Thoracic sarcoidosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view)The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

answers.content: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
answers.explanation_why: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) can manifest subacutely with dyspnea, constitutional symptoms, bilateral crackles on chest auscultation, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen here. In addition, PCP occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals, such as patients with HIV infection. However, chest x-ray in PCP typically shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region, not a unilateral cavitary lesion. Finally, PCP typically occurs at a CD4 count of < 200/mm^3.

images.title: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pneumocystis pneumoniaParenchymal opacification is seen in a predominantly perihilar distribution (green overlay)Pneumocystis pneumonia frequently demonstrates as bilateral perihilar opacification with a fine reticular appearance that progresses to air-space consolidation. On CT, it may appear with a ground-glass appearance. Cystic lesions may also be seen. Atypical findings on imaging include nodules, lymphadenopathy, and effusions.H: heart; SB: stomach bubble

answers.content: Primary tuberculosis
answers.explanation_why:
A productive cough, constitutional symptoms, and chest x-ray findings suggestive of a Ghon complex (hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary lesion) in a patient living in crowded conditions (prison) are strongly suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The lack of improvement of this patient's respiratory symptoms with antibiotic therapy should further raise suspicion for this condition. Pulmonary TB is often accompanied by tuberculous pleurisy, which manifests with chest pain and pleural effusion, as seen in this patient. The patient's chest x-ray findings are consistent with primary tuberculosis, which commonly affects the middle and lower pulmonary lobes. In contrast to primary TB, reactivation TB most commonly affects the upper pulmonary lobes and manifests with multiple cavitary lesions with calcifications and consolidations.

In patients with HIV, reactivated pulmonary TB can also manifest in the lower lobes. The analysis of sputum specimens via culture, microscopy, and/or PCR is the easiest and least invasive way to confirm suspected active pulmonary TB.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.content: Mesothelioma
answers.explanation_why: Pleural mesothelioma (the most common type of mesothelioma) can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, constitutional symptoms, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen in this patient. In addition, mesothelioma develops secondary to asbestos exposure, which this patient might have had while working on construction sites. However, chest x-ray in mesothelioma typically shows multiple nodular pleural lesions seen as pleural thickening, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.

images.title: Diffuse nodular pleural thickening
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesotheliomaNodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

question_text: The patient is hospitalized. On the ward, a medical student is seen entering the patient's room without taking any infection prevention and control measures. The patient's nurse speaks to her when she exits the room and informs her of the required infection prevention precautions. Which of the following isolation precautions is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?
content_preview: The patient is hospitalized. On the ward, a medical student is seen entering the patient's room without taking any infection prevention and control measures. The patient's nurse speaks to her when she exits the room and informs her of the required infection prevention precautions. Which of the following isolation precautions is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?
hint: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is transmitted via infectious particles measuring 1 to 5 μm.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for airborne precautions for patients with active tuberculosis.

answers.content: Droplet precautions
answers.explanation_why: Droplet precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via droplets > 5 μm in size. These measures include the use of surgical masks within a distance of 3–6 feet from the patient. Because tuberculosis is transmitted through even smaller particles that can pass through surgical masks, droplet precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

answers.content: Airborne precautions
answers.explanation_why:
Patients with active tuberculosis (TB) disperse bacilli-containing droplet nuclei (aerosols) while coughing or sneezing, warranting airborne precautions in addition to standard precautions. Patients with suspected or confirmed active TB must be placed in airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) because droplet nuclei can remain suspended in the air and travel long distances. The negative air pressure in AIIRs prevents contaminated air from escaping. Furthermore, patients with active TB must wear surgical face masks in an ambulatory care setting or while being transported to another facility. Health care personnel should wear an N95 respirator (or a higher-level respirator) before entering the AIIR. Airborne precautions for active TB are usually terminated only after the patient has significant clinical improvement, three consecutive negative smears on sputum microscopy (collected 8–24 hours apart), a negative sputum culture, and received treatment for 2–3 weeks.

Other infections requiring airborne precautions include measles, varicella, smallpox, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) infections (e.g., COVID-19).

answers.content: Standard precautions
answers.explanation_why: Standard precautions are used for the care of all patients, whether or not an infection is probable. These measures include respiratory hygiene, but not necessarily wearing a mask. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, standard precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

answers.content: Contact precautions
answers.explanation_why: Contact precautions are used to prevent the transmission of pathogens that spread via direct contact or fomites (e.g., norovirus). These measures include the use of gloves and gowns but not necessarily the use of masks. Because tuberculosis spreads through small particles that enter the respiratory system with the air, contact precautions alone are not sufficient to prevent transmission.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of dry, nonproductive cough. He reports worsening shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue for the past 2 months. He was a miner at a nearby quarry for 10 years and is now a manager there. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment for 20 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. He does not appear to be in acute respiratory distress. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Lung auscultation discloses diffuse fine crackles over the upper lung fields bilaterally; there are no rhonchi or wheezes. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of dry, nonproductive cough. He reports worsening shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue for the past 2 months. He was a miner at a nearby quarry for 10 years and is now a manager there. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment for 20 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. He does not appear to be in acute respiratory distress. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Lung auscultation discloses diffuse fine crackles over the upper lung fields bilaterally; there are no rhonchi or wheezes. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The chest x-ray shows diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy. Another characteristic feature of this condition is eggshell calcification.
learning_objective: Recognize silicosis in a patient with occupational exposure.

answers.content: Anthracosis
answers.explanation_why: Anthracosis is caused by inhalation of carbon dust or sooty air (typically seen in urban environments) and results in heterogeneous pulmonary infiltrates primarily affecting the upper lobes of the lung. However, patients with anthracosis are typically asymptomatic, although they occasionally present with cough and dyspnea. Moreover, anthracosis rarely manifests with pulmonary fibrosis.

answers.content: Asbestosis
answers.explanation_why: Asbestosis is caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers and typically manifests with dyspnea on exertion, dry cough, and fine crackles on lung auscultation. However, asbestosis predominantly affects the lower lobes, and chest x-ray typically shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes. Moreover, asbestosis is commonly seen in individuals who work in the shipbuilding, roofing, or plumbing industries.

images.title: Asbestos-related pleural disease
images.description: Chest X-ray (PA view)Bilateral pleural plaques (indicated by arrowheads), some of which are densely calcified, appear as curvilinear and irregular opacities.The lung opacities (green overlay) raised concern for lung cancer, but biopsy established a diagnosis of cryptococcus infection.

answers.content: Sarcoidosis
answers.explanation_why: Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the pulmonary system and manifests as interstitial fibrosis with chronic cough, dyspnea on exertion, and fatigue. In contrast to this patient's findings, a chest x-ray in sarcoidosis would show hilar lymphadenopathy without upper lobe predominance. Moreover, sarcoidosis may also manifest with extrapulmonary features, such as peripheral lymphadenopathy and ocular (granulomatous uveitis), skin (lupus pernio), and musculoskeletal involvement, none of which are seen here. This patient's occupation makes an exposure-related cause of interstitial lung disease more likely.

images.title: Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosisThe pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

answers.content: Silicosis
answers.explanation_why: This patient's presentation with chronic cough, dyspnea on exertion, and diffuse fine crackles over upper lung fields is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). The most likely cause of this patient's ILD is exposure-related, given his occupation as a quarry worker for 10 years (inhalation of crystalline silica). Silica is typically found below the earth's surface and most commonly affects the upper lobes of the lungs, as seen on this chest x-ray. While silicosis is typically a clinical diagnosis, a lung biopsy would show silicotic nodules. Patients with silicosis are at increased risk for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and should have an annual TB skin test.

answers.content: Berylliosis
answers.explanation_why: Berylliosis typically manifests with progressive dyspnea, cough, and upper lobe involvement with hilar lymphadenopathy. However, berylliosis is typically seen in individuals who work in high-tech sectors, such as the nuclear and aerospace industries, in which the use of beryllium alloys is common. Furthermore, a chest x-ray would show a reticular interstitial pattern of involvement rather than the multiple nodular opacities seen here.

answers.content: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
answers.explanation_why: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically manifests with chronic cough, progressive dyspnea, and fatigue. However, this condition is more commonly seen in farmers because of occupational exposure to certain antigens (e.g., avian protein, animal droppings, microorganisms). Furthermore, a chest x-ray in a patient with chronic exposure would show ground-glass attenuation with honeycombing with or without emphysema, which is not seen in this patient.

images.title: Fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis with mosaic attenuation
images.description: CT chest (inspiratory phase; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP)An irregular reticular pattern of fibrosis predominates in the subpleural regions of the mid zones of the lungs. A small amount of honeycombing (example indicated by red overlay) is seen. There is a heterogeneous pattern of lung attenuation (mosaic attenuation), with areas of low attenuation (examples indicated by green overlays) in some regions with no fibrosis; expiratory phase imaging could help assess whether or not such areas represent air trapping.Fibrotic HP has a variable appearance on CT. A pattern typical of fibrotic HP shows a random axial distribution of coarse reticulation and small airway disease with minimal honeycombing and no zonal predominance. Subpleural fibrosis can be compatible with HP, as can upper zonal, lower zonal, or central predominant distributions.

images.title: Silicosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspneaThere are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.
