question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of chest pain, progressive shortness of breath with exertion, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. The patient also reports daily coughing in the morning that has been worsening over the past few months. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and gout. She worked as an electrician for 35 years and retired 2 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include a tiotropium inhaler and allopurinol. She appears pale and thin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/79 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows asymmetrical chest wall expansion during respiration. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of chest pain, progressive shortness of breath with exertion, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. The patient also reports daily coughing in the morning that has been worsening over the past few months. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and gout. She worked as an electrician for 35 years and retired 2 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include a tiotropium inhaler and allopurinol. She appears pale and thin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/79 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows asymmetrical chest wall expansion during respiration. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Patients with a history of occupational exposure (e.g., handling old electrical insulation) are at increased risk of developing this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize mesothelioma associated with asbestos exposure.

answers.content: Secondary tuberculosis
answers.explanation_why: Secondary tuberculosis can also manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, this patient presents with asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion, which are uncommon in this condition. In addition, a CT scan of a patient with secondary tuberculosis typically shows thick-walled cavitary lesions, centrilobular nodules, and patchy consolidations of the upper lobes rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, this patient has no known history of Mycobacteria exposure and does not have any risk factors (e.g., HIV infection, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus) for tuberculosis reactivation.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.content: Mesothelioma
answers.explanation_why: Mesothelioma is the second most common malignancy (after bronchogenic carcinoma) caused by chronic asbestos exposure, which can occur in individuals working in the insulation industry. Patients typically present with characteristic symptoms of pleural involvement (e.g., chest pain, exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, dullness on chest percussion, decreased breath sounds, asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss). A CT scan of the chest usually shows diffuse pleural thickening with decreased ipsilateral lung volumes, which is also seen here. Although surgery and chemotherapy may provide symptomatic relief, the prognosis remains poor with a mean survival of approx. 12 months after diagnosis.

answers.content: Chronic silicosis
answers.explanation_why: Chronic exposure to silica dust can result in the development of interstitial lung disease, which can manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, this patient presents with asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion, which are uncommon in this condition. Patients with chronic silicosis typically present with diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities and bilateral perihilar calcifications (eggshell calcifications) on chest CT scan rather than diffuse pleural thickening on the left, which is seen here. Furthermore, this patient used to work in the wiring industry, which does not involve silica exposure.

images.title: Silicosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspneaThere are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

answers.content: Lung abscess
answers.explanation_why: A lung abscess can manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, weight loss, and dullness on chest percussion. However, asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration is uncommon, and patients typically present with fever, foul-smelling purulent sputum, and increased rather than decreased breath sounds. In addition, a CT scan usually shows thick-walled, intraparenchymal cavities with air-fluid levels rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, lung abscesses most commonly develop as a result of aspiration, for which this patient has no risk factors.

images.title: Lung abscess
images.description: CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with pneumonia and lung abscessesTwo thick-walled cavitary lesions (green overlay) are seen in the right middle lobe. A sharp air-fluid level is visible within the anterior cavity. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red overlays) are present within the surrounding consolidation.

answers.content: Small cell lung cancer
answers.explanation_why: Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) can develop in individuals with a prolonged history of smoking and chronic exposure to asbestos. Although SCLC can cause chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss, the tumor typically manifests with an irregular, central mass with perihilar node involvement rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here.

images.title: Central lung mass with adenopathy
images.description: CT chest (without contrast; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with small cell lung carcinomaA lobulated central left upper lobe mass (green overlay) is accompanied by bulky lymphadenopathy (examples indicated by red overlay).Small cell lung carcinoma generally presents as a central mass.C: cystic lung lesion

images.title: Diffuse nodular pleural thickening
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesotheliomaNodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

question_text: Five days after admission to the hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia, a 76-year-old man develops watery diarrhea and cramping lower abdominal pain. Today, he has had three episodes of foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea without nausea or vomiting. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, cefotaxime, and clarithromycin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Crackles are heard over the right lower lung base. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm^3. Stool analysis is pending. In addition to isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry, which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the organism responsible for this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
content_preview: Five days after admission to the hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia, a 76-year-old man develops watery diarrhea and cramping lower abdominal pain. Today, he has had three episodes of foul-smelling, nonbloody diarrhea without nausea or vomiting. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, cefotaxime, and clarithromycin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Crackles are heard over the right lower lung base. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3. Stool analysis is pending. In addition to isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry, which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the organism responsible for this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
hint: Clostridioides difficile infection, which typically occurs after initiating broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, is the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (i.e., foul-smelling watery diarrhea, abdominal pain).
learning_objective: Recognize the need for hand washing with soap and water to prevent C. difficile transmission.

answers.content: Wear an N95 respirator
answers.explanation_why:
Health care providers wear an N95 respirator as part of airborne precautions when caring for patients with diseases spread by person-to-person airborne transmission (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require airborne precautions.

Legionnaire disease (LD), which causes acute pneumonia and GI symptoms (e.g., watery diarrhea, abdominal pain), can spread in hospitals via airborne transmission as a result of aerosol generation from a contaminated water source (e.g., through an airconditioning unit or shower). However, patients with LD usually develop pneumonia and GI symptoms simultaneously, unlike this patient who developed GI symptoms 5 days after being admitted for pneumonia. Moreover, transmission-based precautions (e.g., airborne precautions) are not indicated when caring for patients with LD because person-to-person transmission of LD is extremely rare.

answers.content: Use an alcohol-based hand rub
answers.explanation_why: Alcohol-based foam or gel hand rubs are quick to use and more effective against most organisms than other hand hygiene methods, but they are ineffective against spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile.

answers.content: No further infection control measures are required
answers.explanation_why: Health care providers should always follow standard precautions for infection control regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. Standard precautions are not fulfilled by only isolating the patient and wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry.

answers.content: Wash hands with soap and water
answers.explanation_why:
Adequate hand hygiene, which is a standard precaution, should always be performed by health care providers (HCPs) for infection control before and after contact with a patient, regardless of whether or not the patient has an infection. In most instances, the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (ABHRs) alone is a quicker and superior method of hand hygiene than washing hands with soap and water. However, hand hygiene with soap and water rather than an ABHR is required if the HCP's hands are visibly soiled or when caring for patients with acute infectious diarrhea or infections due to spore-forming organisms such as C. difficile, because ABHRs are ineffective against spores. Wearing gloves and a gown is an important adjunct in preventing contamination with spores but is not a substitute for hand hygiene. HCPs should wash hands with soap and water before putting on gloves and gowns as well as after removing them.

When caring for patients with contact-transmitted diseases such as C. difficile infection, in addition to standard precautions, HCPs should follow contact precautions (e.g., isolating patients, wearing gloves and a gown upon room entry).

answers.content: Wear a surgical mask
answers.explanation_why: When caring for patients, health care providers should wear a surgical mask as part of standard precautions when there is a risk of exposure to body fluids or other potentially infectious material (e.g., when performing a procedure that can generate splashes or sprays) and as a part of droplet precautions (e.g., when within 3–6 feet of a patient with a droplet-transmitted infection). Prevention of C. difficile transmission does not require droplet precautions; a different element of standard precautions prevents transmission.

question_text: A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated?
content_preview: A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated?
hint: A physician who is impaired (e.g., an intoxicated surgeon) has a higher risk of committing a medical error that causes injury to the patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the principle of nonmaleficence in patient care.

answers.content: Beneficence
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, beneficence refers to acting in the best interest of the patient (“do good”). Surgical management of appendicitis in this patient is in his best interest. However, the surgeon's intoxicated state impairs the safety of the procedure and puts the patient at risk of harm due to a medical error. While it is the intention of the surgeon to do good, the principle to “do no harm” would be violated if she continued with the procedure in her impaired state.

answers.content: Justice
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, justice refers to treating patients fairly and equitably, i.e., treatment is determined by the patient's specific medical needs (in contrast to treating all patients the same way). This patient needs an emergency appendectomy and is scheduled for this procedure, so the principle of justice is upheld.

answers.content: Autonomy
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, autonomy refers to a patient or guardian's right to make decisions about whether or not to undergo treatment. This patient is legally emancipated, retained full decision-making capacities at the time of the diagnosis, and a surgical resident obtained informed consent for the procedure. The principle of patient autonomy is therefore respected.

answers.content: Nonmaleficence
answers.explanation_why:
Nonmaleficence is the medical ethical principle of avoiding patient injury or suffering (i.e., “do no harm”). Most decisions in patient care require weighing the principle of nonmaleficence against the principle of beneficence (i.e., acting in the patient's best interest). In this scenario, the patient has an indication for an emergency appendectomy, and surgical management is in his best interest (principle of beneficence). However, the patient is at risk of serious harm due to physician impairment, and this risk cannot be outweighed by the benefits of having the procedure done by an impaired physician. The operating room staff needs to prevent the surgeon from performing the appendectomy and find a substitute surgeon.

In addition, the Physician Health Program (PHP) should be informed about the incident. The PHP will perform a thorough assessment of the physician and arrange appropriate management and support if an impairment is confirmed. Note that the PHP is not obliged to notify the state medical board if the physician accepts treatment of the impairing condition.

question_text: A 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department two hours after an episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. He did not cough blood during this episode. His symptoms resolved spontaneously after 15 minutes. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Medical history is significant for tobacco use disorder and panic disorder, for which the patient takes sertraline. He appears anxious. Pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no leg asymmetry or edema. ECG is normal. The emergency room physician determines that the patient has a very low probability of having a pulmonary embolism, but decides to order a serum D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. The physician's decision was most likely subject to which of the following types of bias?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department two hours after an episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. He did not cough blood during this episode. His symptoms resolved spontaneously after 15 minutes. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Medical history is significant for tobacco use disorder and panic disorder, for which the patient takes sertraline. He appears anxious. Pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no leg asymmetry or edema. ECG is normal. The emergency room physician determines that the patient has a very low probability of having a pulmonary embolism, but decides to order a serum D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. The physician's decision was most likely subject to which of the following types of bias?
hint: This patient's history of panic disorder and 15-minute episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating indicates a panic attack.
learning_objective: Recall the definition of commission bias in clinical decision-making.

answers.content: Availability bias
answers.explanation_why: Availability bias is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. An example of availability bias would be a situation in which the physician orders serum D-dimer testing to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE) because he recently missed a diagnosis of PE in a different patient.

answers.content: Visceral bias
answers.explanation_why: Visceral bias is the tendency for clinical decisions to be influenced by positive or negative feelings towards the patient. An example of visceral bias would be a situation in which the physician doubts the symptoms described by a patient with substance use disorder. There are no indications that the emergency room physician has any positive or negative feelings towards this man.

answers.content: Confirmation bias
answers.explanation_why: Confirmation bias (psychology) is the tendency to favor evidence that supports preconceived notions, ignoring other results. This physician ordered a D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism (PE). There is no indication that he has preconceived expectations of PE and is now collecting evidence to confirm the diagnosis.

answers.content: Gender bias
answers.explanation_why: Gender bias occurs when assumptions about an individual are incorrectly based on the individual's real or perceived gender. This physician based the decision for D-dimer on the patient's presenting symptoms and concern about having a lung condition. There is no indication that the patient's gender had a significant influence on the physician's decision.

answers.content: Commission bias
answers.explanation_why:
Commission bias is favoring action (e.g., ordering a D-dimer test) over inaction when inaction will likely lead to the same or a better outcome. This patient most likely has had a panic attack. His Wells score for pulmonary embolism (PE) indicates a low probability for PE and the pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (total score of 0 points) indicate that no further diagnostic testing is needed. Regardless of these facts, the physician has ordered a D-dimer test most likely as a result of a sense of obligation to the principle of beneficence.

Commission bias is less common in health care than omission bias, which is the tendency to prefer inaction over action.

question_text: A 28-year-old man who is a physician assistant at a community clinic comes to the office because he is concerned about having acquired a bloodborne infection. Eight months ago, he sustained a needlestick injury while providing local anesthesia for the incision and drainage of an abscess in a woman with unknown HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), and hepatitis C virus (HCV) status. He is vaccinated against HBV and had adequate titers of anti-HBs at the time of the injury. He was prescribed tenofovir, emtricitabine, and dolutegravir immediately after the injury but had to discontinue these medications after 1 week because of nausea and vomiting. The results of the previous HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay performed 4 months ago and the previous anti-HCV antibody titer test performed 2 months ago were negative. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study at this time?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man who is a physician assistant at a community clinic comes to the office because he is concerned about having acquired a bloodborne infection. Eight months ago, he sustained a needlestick injury while providing local anesthesia for the incision and drainage of an abscess in a woman with unknown HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), and hepatitis C virus (HCV) status. He is vaccinated against HBV and had adequate titers of anti-HBs at the time of the injury. He was prescribed tenofovir, emtricitabine, and dolutegravir immediately after the injury but had to discontinue these medications after 1 week because of nausea and vomiting. The results of the previous HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay performed 4 months ago and the previous anti-HCV antibody titer test performed 2 months ago were negative. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study at this time?
hint: If seroconversion occurs following exposure to HIV or HCV, it almost always occurs within the first few months. This principle guides the management after a needle stick injury (NSI).
learning_objective: Recognize the guidelines for post-exposure prophylaxis follow-up, and recall when no further workup is indicated.

answers.content: Repeat an anti-HCV antibody titer test
answers.explanation_why: After an NSI involving a source patient with an unknown HCV status, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test followed by an HCV nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. This patient had a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI and requires no further testing for HCV infection.

answers.content: Perform an HCV nucleic acid amplification test
answers.explanation_why: After an NSI involving a source patient with an unknown HCV status, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test followed by an HCV nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. HCV NAAT would also be performed for any patient with a positive anti-HCV antibody test in order to confirm HCV infection. This patient had a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI and requires no further testing for HCV infection.

answers.content: No further workup is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why:
After an NSI, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline antibody-based HIV test (preferably the HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay) and, if the source patient's HIV status is positive or unknown, follow-up testing at 6 weeks and 4 months (if using the HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay) or at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months (if using a previous generation antibody-based test). Extended follow-up testing for HIV (e.g., at 1 year after the NSI) is only required if the exposed individual becomes HCV-positive or has impaired humoral immunity because delayed HIV seroconversion can occur in these patients. The decision to initiate postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) against HIV after NSI is made using a shared-decision making strategy based on a risk-benefit analysis (e.g., source patient status, drug toxicities).

Following NSI, provided the source patient has a negative HCV status, no further testing for HCV is required in the exposed individual. If the source patient's HCV status is positive or unknown, the exposed individual should undergo a baseline anti-HCV antibody test and follow-up with an HCV nucleic acid amplification test at 3–6 weeks and an anti-HCV antibody test at 4–6 months. Currently, no PEP against HCV is recommended, but exposed individuals who become HCV-positive should receive direct-acting antiviral therapy.

If the source patient has a negative HBV status or if the exposed individual had adequate anti-HBs titers, no further testing or PEP against HBV is required. If the exposed individual had inadequate titers and the source patient's HBV status is positive or unknown, the exposed individual should receive PEP against HBV with active and passive immunization and undergo follow-up testing with anti-HBc and HBsAg at 6 months.

answers.content: Perform an HIV nucleic acid amplification test
answers.explanation_why: A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for HIV is used as a tiebreaker test in a serial testing strategy (e.g., after a positive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay but a negative HIV antigen-antibody differentiation assay) in order to diagnose HIV infection. A quantitative NAAT (e.g., real-time polymerase chain reaction), which can measure viral loads, is used to measure response to treatment in patients with confirmed HIV infection and to screen for HIV in children younger than 18 months born to mothers with HIV infection (antibodies can cross the placenta which can cause false positives). With the exception of congenital HIV infection, NAAT is not used as the initial test to diagnose HIV infection or for the follow-up of patients without a confirmed HIV infection because this test has a higher rate of false positives than antibody-based tests and undetectable HIV RNA does not rule out HIV transmission.

answers.content: Repeat an HIV combination immunoassay test
answers.explanation_why: After an NSI, follow-up testing with an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay beyond 4 months is only required if the exposed individual becomes HCV-positive or has a history suggestive of impaired humoral immunity because delayed HIV seroconversion occurs in these patients. This patient, who is otherwise healthy, had a negative HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay 4 months after the NSI and a negative anti-HCV antibody test 6 months after the NSI; he, therefore, requires no further testing for HIV infection.

question_text: The administrative heads of a preferred provider organization (PPO) want to improve the quality of care received by patients at their affiliated cardiology departments while maintaining cost efficiency. They assess the baseline quality of care by gathering data on the number of board-certified cardiologists affiliated with their PPO, provider-to-patient ratios, and the number of nursing hours per patient per day in their cardiology departments. Which of the following terms best describes the measures used by the PPO to assess their quality of care?
content_preview: The administrative heads of a preferred provider organization (PPO) want to improve the quality of care received by patients at their affiliated cardiology departments while maintaining cost efficiency. They assess the baseline quality of care by gathering data on the number of board-certified cardiologists affiliated with their PPO, provider-to-patient ratios, and the number of nursing hours per patient per day in their cardiology departments. Which of the following terms best describes the measures used by the PPO to assess their quality of care?
hint: The Donabedian model identifies several types of quality measures to assess and compare different aspects of quality in a health care system.
learning_objective: Recognize the type of quality measurement based on the Donabedian model.

answers.content: Outcome
answers.explanation_why: Outcome measures assess the final impact of services provided by a health care facility on patients' health status. An example of an outcome measure would be the 30-day mortality rate of patients who are admitted with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. In this case, the PPO evaluates the resources available at their facility, not the final impact of their services on patients.

answers.content: Process
answers.explanation_why: Process measures evaluate whether health care procedures such as diagnostic tests, treatments, and preventive care are performed in accordance with current standards. An example of a process measure would be the percentage of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension who are on ACE inhibitors. In this case, the PPO evaluates the resources available at their facility, not the procedures per se.

answers.content: Composite
answers.explanation_why: Composite measures, which aggregate structural, process, and outcome measures in a single score, provide a comprehensive overview of a health care facility's performance. In this case, the PPO evaluates only one domain of the health care quality (i.e., resources available at the facility), which is not a composite measure.

answers.content: Balancing
answers.explanation_why: Balancing measures assess whether changes in one part of a health care system have an unintended impact on another part of the system (e.g., whether readmission rates increase after an initiative to reduce the average length of stay). In this case, the PPO evaluates the resources available at their health care facility, which is better described by a different term.

answers.content: Structural
answers.explanation_why: Structural measures evaluate the material, organizational, and professional resources (e.g., equipment, facilities, staff) available at a health care facility. Examples include the evaluation of the number of beds, volume of surgeries performed, usage of medication order entry systems, and provision of digital copies of health records to patients. A facility's structural characteristics affect other domains of healthcare quality, which can be assessed via process measures, outcome measures, balancing measures, and composite measures. Composite measures aggregate several types of quality measures into a single score and allow a comprehensive view of the overall performance of a health care system.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
hint: This patient's behavior and posture indicates a risk of impending violence. When confronted with an aggressive or violent patient, the health care provider (HCP)'s first priority is to ensure personal safety and attempt to deescalate the situation.
learning_objective: Recognize strategies for ensuring personal safety and deescalating aggressive behavior in patients.

answers.content: Use the additional personnel to set up a four-point restraint on the patient
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the use of force, such as physical restraints (e.g., a four-point restraint) or chemical restraints, should be a last resort.

answers.content: Stand between the patient and the ED exit and request that the patient take a sedative medication orally
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should position themself closer to the exit than the patient to ensure an escape route in case the aggressive behavior escalates. If a chemical restraint is indicated, it is also appropriate for the HCP to request that the patient voluntarily take the calming medication orally before considering use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation). However, the HCP should not block the exit by standing between the patient and the exit, because this action can be perceived as threatening and lead to escalation of the aggressive behavior. Moreover the HCP should attempt verbal deescalation before considering the use of a chemical restraint.

answers.content: Take turns speaking to the patient with another health care provider
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, it is important to have other HCPs nearby to provide assistance in case the aggressive behavior escalates. However, only one HCP should talk to the patient to avoid confusion and further escalation.

answers.content: Step two arm lengths away from the patient and offer the patient food and water
answers.explanation_why:
To ensure personal safety when dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should step two arm lengths away and position themselves closer to the exit (so that there is an escape route) without blocking the patient's view or access to the exit. The HCP should then attempt verbal deescalation. Offering comfort measures (e.g., food, water) is an appropriate initial step. During verbal deescalation, only one HCP should talk to the patient; the HCP should remain calm, maintain a neutral expression, respect the patient's personal space, and avoid gestures that can be perceived as threatening (e.g., sudden movement, staring back at the patient, expressing a condescending or commanding attitude). The HCP should acknowledge the patient's feelings, ask what the patient wants, and allow the patient to choose between different acceptable options (e.g., sitting down or lying down); doing so gives the patient a sense of control while also clarifying rules and limits (e.g., informing the patient that violent or abusive behavior will not be accepted). The HCP should listen actively, use short sentences and simple words, seek out points on which they and the patient can agree, and give the patient time to process information and respond.

If the patient continues to remain aggressive despite attempts at verbal deescalation, it is appropriate to ask the patient to voluntarily take a calming medication orally before considering use of force. The use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation) should only be considered if all other measures fail or if the patient is actively violent. Physical restraints and/or involuntary sedation should not be used as punishment and should be removed as soon as feasible.

answers.content: Sit next to the patient and maintain eye contact in silence until the patient calms down
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should maintain a safe distance to ensure personal safety and attempt to speak to the patient in a calm tone to deescalate the situation. The HCP should avoid maintaining eye contact because it can be perceived as a threatening gesture and lead to escalation of aggressive behavior by the patient.

question_text: A 75-year-old man who is being treated in the hospital for new-onset congestive heart failure alerts his nurse because he is feeling unwell. He reports feeling dizzy and nauseous and that he had to lie down again after trying to stand up to go to the bathroom. He says that his symptoms began 30 minutes after he was brought back to the ward from the radiology department, where he underwent a CT scan of the chest to evaluate an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest x-ray. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease and hypertension. After admission, bisoprolol therapy was temporarily discontinued and he was started on furosemide. His other medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The physician on call takes the patient’s vital signs and measures a pulse of 138/min and blood pressure of 95/70 mm Hg. Further investigation reveals that the changes in the patient's pulse and blood pressure were not detected despite continuous cardiac telemetry being a part of the patient's admission orders. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the error that occurred in this scenario?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man who is being treated in the hospital for new-onset congestive heart failure alerts his nurse because he is feeling unwell. He reports feeling dizzy and nauseous and that he had to lie down again after trying to stand up to go to the bathroom. He says that his symptoms began 30 minutes after he was brought back to the ward from the radiology department, where he underwent a CT scan of the chest to evaluate an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest x-ray. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease and hypertension. After admission, bisoprolol therapy was temporarily discontinued and he was started on furosemide. His other medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The physician on call takes the patient’s vital signs and measures a pulse of 138/min and blood pressure of 95/70 mm Hg. Further investigation reveals that the changes in the patient's pulse and blood pressure were not detected despite continuous cardiac telemetry being a part of the patient's admission orders. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the error that occurred in this scenario?
hint: Cardiac telemetry can interfere with the image quality of chest CT scans by causing a beam hardening artifact.
learning_objective: Recognize the common causes of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors.

answers.content: Failure at the patient-telemetry device interface
answers.explanation_why: When humans interact with medical equipment, three types of errors occur: human errors, device errors, and errors at the level of the device-human interface. Failure at the level of the device-human interface (e.g., disconnection of the patient from or improper connection of the patient to the telemetry device) is the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors (approx. 50% of cases) and typically occurs after patients are shifted (e.g., for a test). Less common causes of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors are equipment malfunction (25%), communication breakdown (20%), and alarm fatigue (5%). Cardiac telemetry-related errors rarely cause patients to be harmed, but when they do, the consequences are dire with death as the most frequent outcome. Measures that can be taken to prevent such errors include checklists and standardization for inpatient transfers, regular telemetry equipment checks, forcing functions that prevent alarms from being turned down, and redirection of low-level alarms to telemetry technicians to prevent alarm fatigue in nurses.

answers.content: Poor communication of telemetry events
answers.explanation_why: Poor communication between healthcare providers about cardiac telemetry events (e.g., when nurses or telemetry technicians fail to notify physicians about alarms) can lead to adequate care being delayed or not initiated at all after an event has been detected. However, poor communication is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.

answers.content: Desensitization to alarms from the telemetry device
answers.explanation_why: Desensitization of health care providers to alarms from the telemetry device (i.e., alarm fatigue) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is an uncommon cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors.

answers.content: Malfunctioning of the telemetry device
answers.explanation_why: Malfunctioning of the cardiac telemetry device (e.g., due to empty batteries in the case of a portable device) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss the results of a colonoscopy performed 1 week ago. The patient immigrated to the USA from Indonesia 4 years ago. She is accompanied by her daughter and a friend. The woman and her daughter have both been patients at the physician's practice but the physician does not know the patient's friend. The office is relatively small and everything that is said can be heard by everyone present in the room. After a self-introduction and greeting everyone in the room, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss the results of a colonoscopy performed 1 week ago. The patient immigrated to the USA from Indonesia 4 years ago. She is accompanied by her daughter and a friend. The woman and her daughter have both been patients at the physician's practice but the physician does not know the patient's friend. The office is relatively small and everything that is said can be heard by everyone present in the room. After a self-introduction and greeting everyone in the room, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: The disclosure of personal health information (PHI) to third parties is appropriate under certain circumstances.
learning_objective: Recognize the need to obtain patient consent before discussing personal health information in the presence of bystanders.

answers.content: Politely ask all bystanders to leave the room
answers.explanation_why: This course of action would be appropriate if the patient objects to the bystanders being present during the visit. In many cultures, it is common for family members to be present during healthcare visits, as they are considered an essential part of the decision-making process. At the start of the patient interview, the physician should apply a patient-centered approach and first ascertain the patient's individual preferences regarding the presence of bystanders.

answers.content: Begin the consultation with the bystanders in the room
answers.explanation_why: This course of action would be appropriate if the patient states that they want both bystanders to be present during the visit. In the US, patients with full decision-making capacity, regardless of their cultural background, need to give permission for their PHI to be disclosed. It would therefore not be appropriate to begin the consultation without ascertaining the patient's individual preferences first.

answers.content: Ask the patient whether she would like the bystanders to be present
answers.explanation_why:
Family, friends, and caregivers commonly accompany patients to health care visits, which can have certain benefits (e.g., if they can provide additional information about the patient's health, give emotional support, or facilitate communication between the patient and physician), but also challenges (e.g., regarding patient confidentiality and potential influence on the patient's decision-making). Patients with decision-making capacity need to give informal permission for their PHI to be disclosed to bystanders, even if they are the patient's next of kin or friend. In order to protect patient confidentiality, the physician should employ a patient-centered approach and discuss the patient's individual preferences. By asking for the patient's permission for the bystanders to be present, the physician acknowledges the patient's autonomy, which can strengthen the patient-physician relationship.

If the patient gives permission for the bystanders to be present, physicians should try to determine the relationship between the patient and the bystanders and assess the reason for their presence during the visit. If necessary, physicians should also ensure that there is time for a private conversation during the visit.

answers.content: Politely ask the patient's friend to leave the room
answers.explanation_why: This course of action would be appropriate if the patient objects to their friend being present during the visit. Bystanders are generally allowed to be present during health care visits if the patient gives their permission, even if they are not next of kin. In order to apply a patient-centered approach, the physician should first ascertain the patient's individual preferences regarding the presence of bystanders.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4^th to 6^th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. Two hours later, the patient is brought to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, dyspnea, and nausea. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this medical error?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4th to 6th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. Two hours later, the patient is brought to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, dyspnea, and nausea. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this medical error?
hint: The physician failed to consider alternative diagnoses (e.g., myocardial infarction) for this patient's chest pain.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of premature closure in medical decision-making.

answers.content: Commission bias
answers.explanation_why: Commission bias is a cognitive bias in which the physician chooses action or intervention when inaction would have resulted in a similar or better outcome (e.g., excessive testing in a low-risk patient). In this scenario, the physician chose inaction (no further testing) over action (performing an ECG). This is an example of omission bias rather than commission bias. There is another term that better describes the main cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario.

answers.content: Conjunction fallacy
answers.explanation_why: Conjunction fallacy is a logical error in which the probability of multiple coinciding events (e.g., diagnoses) is assumed to be higher than the probability of a single event. The physician in this scenario assumed that the patient was more likely to have one condition (costochondritis) than multiple conditions (costochondritis and myocardial infarction), so conjunction fallacy does not apply. The physician made an immediate diagnosis without considering alternative diagnoses. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

answers.content: Zebra retreat
answers.explanation_why: Zebra retreat bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician is reluctant to consider a rare diagnosis even though there is evidence that supports the diagnosis. Myocardial infarction is a common condition that should be considered in all patients with chest pain and risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The physician in this scenario made an immediate diagnosis (costochondritis) while failing to consider a common alternative diagnosis (myocardial infarction). The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

answers.content: Information bias
answers.explanation_why: Information bias (psychology) is the tendency to seek more information (e.g., in support of a diagnosis) than is necessary or relevant for making a decision. In this scenario, the physician made a diagnosis (costochondritis) without further verification. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

answers.content: Premature closure
answers.explanation_why:
Premature closure bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician makes a premature diagnosis without further verification, thereby increasing the risk of diagnostic errors such as misdiagnosis and delayed diagnosis. In this scenario, the physician immediately made a diagnosis (costochondritis) and failed to consider an alternative cause for the patient’s chest pain (myocardial infarction). The physician should have taken the patient’s risk factors for cardiovascular disease (i.e., older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension) into account and performed further diagnostic testing. An electrocardiogram is indicated for patients > 35 years of age with suspected costochondritis. If the physician had been aware of his cognitive bias, myocardial infarction could have been diagnosed at the office, which may have improved the patient's outcome. Strategies to avoid cognitive biases include education on cognitive errors, diagnostic time-outs, differential diagnosis generators, and checklists.

In many situations, several cognitive errors can occur simultaneously. Omission bias, overconfidence, and availability bias may have also occurred in this scenario.

question_text:
The head of a private urology practice is evaluating the results of a recent patient satisfaction survey. The results indicate that patients consider the time from registration to departure to be too long. The practice identifies the different components of a patient's visit and times how long each one takes. The results are shown:

Registration
Measuring vital parameters
Patient interview
Obtaining blood samples
Scheduling follow-up visits

Mean (min)
4
8
20
8
6

Standard deviation (min)
0.5
5
6
3
2

Optimization of which of the following components is most likely to have the greatest impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit?
content_preview: The head of a private urology practice is evaluating the results of a recent patient satisfaction survey. The results indicate that patients consider the time from registration to departure to be too long. The practice identifies the different components of a patient's visit and times how long each one takes. The results are shown: Registration Measuring vital parameters Patient interview Obtaining blood samples Scheduling follow-up visits Mean (min) 4 8 20 8 6 Standard deviation (min) 0.5 5 6 3 2 Optimization of which of the following components is most likely to have the greatest impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit?
hint: The coefficient of variation (CV) can be used to measure and compare the dispersion around the mean of multiple data sets. CV = standard deviation (SD) ÷ mean.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of coefficient of variation to identify processes for optimization.

answers.content: Registration
answers.explanation_why: Registration has the lowest CV (0.5 ÷ 4 = 0.12). Registration is also the shortest component of the visit, and, therefore, optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

answers.content: Obtaining blood samples
answers.explanation_why: Obtaining blood samples does not have the highest CV (3 ÷ 8 = 0.38). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

answers.content: Patient interview
answers.explanation_why: The patient interview is the longest component of the visit with a mean time of 20 minutes. However, the patient interview process does not have the highest CV (6 ÷ 20 = 0.30) and therefore does not have the greatest variation in duration relative to the mean. Some variation in the duration of patient interviews is expected and necessary, as each patient's needs are unique, and care should be personalized accordingly. Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

answers.content: Measuring vital parameters
answers.explanation_why:
CV, which is a statistical relative measure of dispersion, allows SD to be interpreted relative to the mean, allowing for the comparison of multiple data sets that may have means of different magnitudes or units of measurement, as CV is dimensionless. A high CV indicates that values are widely spread around the mean. In a system with multiple processes, such as the various aspects of a patient's visit, the process with the highest CV should be optimized first to improve the system's overall reliability and efficiency. Optimization of vital parameter measurements, which has the highest CV (5 ÷ 8 = 0.62), will therefore most likely have the greatest impact on reducing the average time that patients spend in the practice.

In contrast, SD, which is an absolute measure of dispersion, describes the variability of data in relation to the mean within a single data set.

answers.content: Scheduling follow-up visits
answers.explanation_why: Scheduling follow-up visits does not have the highest CV (2 ÷ 6 = 0.33). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

question_text: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
content_preview: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
hint: Physician A's behavior violates the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical principles violated by physician misconduct.

answers.content: Malpractice
answers.explanation_why: Medical malpractice occurs when a healthcare provider violates professional standards through negligent conduct or acts of omission, resulting in patient harm. The elements of malpractice (i.e., the 4 Ds) are the duty to properly treat the patient, dereliction of that duty, damage to the patient, and direct cause of damage through medical negligence. Although Physician A neglected the duty to treat his patients, none have been directly damaged. Therefore, he did not commit malpractice and a different term describes his actions.

answers.content: Misconduct
answers.explanation_why: Physician misconduct is any behavior that goes against the ethical principles of medical practice. In this scenario, physician A leaves the hospital and puts patients at risk through his absence, which violates the principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence. This behavior is never acceptable regardless of whether it results in harm to a patient or incurs legal consequences. Misconduct can also occur outside the established physician-patient relationship and does not always constitute malpractice (e.g., research malfeasance, fraudulent advertising). Other examples of misconduct include bullying, making inappropriate comments and/or sexually harassing colleagues or patients, billing fraud, and receiving gifts from patients or pharmaceutical industry representatives. Colleagues who suspect a physician of misconduct should report their concerns to the state medical board, and, if the misconduct implies any legal liability, to the appropriate legal authorities.

answers.content: Slip
answers.explanation_why: Slip is an unintentional active error in the performance of a task that is caused by a lack of mindful attention (e.g., accidentally pushing the bolus button instead of giving the medication in infusion). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

answers.content: Mistake
answers.explanation_why: A mistake is a failed outcome resulting from an intentional action because of an error in execution and/or planning (e.g., making a misdiagnosis during an emergency and subsequently performing the wrong diagnostic test). Mistakes are more likely to occur while under time pressure, during multitasking and the execution of complex tasks, and when there is a lack of experience. Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

answers.content: Lapse
answers.explanation_why: A lapse is an unintentional active error caused by a lack of mindful attention and a fault in memory (e.g., forgetting about a patient's penicillin allergy and prescribing amoxicillin). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

question_text: After a history of adverse outcomes in a small rural hospital, a quality and safety inspector is evaluating the communication between physicians in the emergency department. A team of two residents and one attending physician is responsible for patient care during the night. After their shift ends, a new team of three physicians takes over. The inspector is observing the transfer of patient information from the team of physicians working the night shift to the incoming day team. Which of the following is the most appropriate action during a handoff to ensure patient safety?
content_preview: After a history of adverse outcomes in a small rural hospital, a quality and safety inspector is evaluating the communication between physicians in the emergency department. A team of two residents and one attending physician is responsible for patient care during the night. After their shift ends, a new team of three physicians takes over. The inspector is observing the transfer of patient information from the team of physicians working the night shift to the incoming day team. Which of the following is the most appropriate action during a handoff to ensure patient safety?
hint: During a handoff, information and responsibility for patient care are transferred from one team or physician to another.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of communicating critical information and recommendations for anticipated events during patient handoffs.

answers.content: Provide recommendations for anticipated events
answers.explanation_why:
During a handoff, the senders (the outgoing team) should prioritize communicating critical information, tasks (i.e., to-do items), and recommendations for anticipated events (i.e., if/then items) to the receivers (the incoming team). For example, “If the patient develops dyspnea, administer 40 mg of intravenous furosemide.” is an if/then item. Receivers should be able to ask questions and discuss uncertainties; therefore, handoffs should consist of verbal communication, preferably face-to-face, at a designated time and place free of nonemergency disturbances. Written communication (e.g., electronic health records, checklists, protocols) can be used as a complementary tool.

Standardized handoff communication tools (e.g., IPASS, SBAR) ensure consistency in the exchange of relevant patient information among physicians.

answers.content: Request a read-back from the incoming team for all action items
answers.explanation_why: During a handoff, a read-back can ensure that the receiver has correctly understood the information given by the sender. However, a read-back should only be requested for critical items to ensure the timely transfer of high-priority information to the receiver.

answers.content: Designate a single provider to be responsible for conducting the handoff
answers.explanation_why: Designating a single provider to conduct the handoff is inappropriate because they may not have complete, up-to-date knowledge about the status of all patients. Any break in the continuity of care could cause harm to a patient. Therefore, all outgoing and incoming team members should attend the handoff.

answers.content: Conduct the handoff in a written format only
answers.explanation_why: Written communication (e.g., electronic health records, checklists, protocols) is used as a supportive tool during a handoff. However, conducting a handoff solely in a written format is inappropriate because verbal communication is necessary for asking questions, discussing uncertainties, and assessing the receiver's level of knowledge.

answers.content: Perform a detailed bedside round for each patient
answers.explanation_why: Bedside handoffs may be necessary to discuss critically ill patients. However, because of the numerous distractions at the bedside, communication between physicians may be interrupted, and relevant information could be missed. Handoffs should generally take place in a designated area free of nonemergency disturbances, allowing physicians to focus on information transfer.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon?
hint: This strategy, which is also considered when prescribing biological immunosuppressants, aims to control costs and provide only the necessary care.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for prior authorization for elective procedures with HMO insurance.

answers.content: Defer knee surgery until a request for reimbursement is approved by the HMO
answers.explanation_why: Prior authorization (PA) is a process used by health insurance companies to evaluate the medical necessity and cost of medications, tests, and treatments in order to approve coverage before they are provided to the patient. Health insurance companies usually require PA for elective and expensive interventions that have lower-cost alternatives (e.g., arthroplasty). PA is obtained to ensure that the health insurance company will cover the requested care, protecting patients from financial liability. If a health care provider is in-network, they are responsible for determining whether an intervention needs PA and for submitting the request form to the health insurance company. Treatment should only be provided after the health insurance company has reviewed and approved the request.
answers.explanation_but: Many health care providers have called for reforming of the PA process because of its detrimental impact on patient care. PAs are widely considered to be a time-consuming administrative burden that can result in delays in care and adverse clinical outcomes. Submitting requests electronically can help reduce administrative time and speed up the process of obtaining PA.

answers.content: Perform the knee surgery and ask the primary care physician to submit a pre-claim review to the HMO
answers.explanation_why: A pre-claim review requests provisional confirmation of coverage after treatment but before the submission of a final claim for payment. Because total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage by the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is preferred. In addition, the treating physician is responsible for submitting a pre-claim review.

answers.content: Ask the patient to seek approval from the HMO for reimbursement prior to surgery
answers.explanation_why: Approval from the HMO is required prior to certain types of interventions, especially expensive treatments and those with lower-cost alternatives (e.g., total knee arthroplasty). However, the patient is not responsible for seeking approval for treatments given by in-network providers.

answers.content: Inform the patient that she has to pay out of pocket because HMOs do not cover elective orthopedic surgeries
answers.explanation_why: Patients with HMOs must pay out of pocket for services by out-of-network providers. However, this patient's surgeon is in-network, and HMOs cover elective orthopedic surgeries that are considered medically necessary.

answers.content: Perform the knee surgery and then submit a reimbursement claim to the HMO
answers.explanation_why: Submitting a reimbursement claim to the HMO after treatment can be considered in emergency situations. However, because a total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage from the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is more appropriate.

question_text: A 72-year-old man is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care physician for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 3 years ago. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care physician's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the physician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, “I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time.” Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care physician for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 3 years ago. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care physician's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the physician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, “I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time.” Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management?
hint: To ensure the quality of care and avoid patient harm, critical imaging results should be communicated with the referring physician in a timely manner.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for timely verbal communication of critical imaging results between providers.

answers.content: Computerized alert notifications for the primary care physician upon uploading of the radiology report
answers.explanation_why: Alert notifications can help physicians receive critical results in a timely manner. However, because physicians often receive an increased amount of notifications, they may not read all alerts and fail to acknowledge critical results (alert fatigue).

answers.content: Explanation of the imaging findings to the patient by the radiologist in person
answers.explanation_why: The radiologist may explain critical findings to a patient if the referring physician cannot be contacted in a timely manner or if management will be affected because of delays. However, because the referring physician will provide further management and has also likely built a trusting relationship with the patient, critical test results should be communicated by them whenever possible.

answers.content: Sending concrete follow-up recommendations and a compact disc of the images to the primary care physician via registered mail
answers.explanation_why: Follow-up recommendations (e.g., additional diagnostic studies) by the interpreting physician can help the referring physician plan further management. However, mailing records is not the fastest or most efficient method and would not have prevented delays in management. In general, electronic communication of critical imaging results is preferred over paper-based reporting.

answers.content: Verbal communication of imaging results between the providers via phone
answers.explanation_why:
In addition to the electronically sent report, critical imaging results should be delivered through additional means of communication that ensure timely receipt of the findings. Verbal communication between providers, either in person or via phone, is recommended as it allows the receiving physician to acknowledge receipt of the information, facilitates further discussion, and is likely to prompt timely follow-up actions. Any additional communication between providers should be properly documented (e.g., method of communication, name of the person who received the information).

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame.

answers.content: Asking the patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly until the imaging results are available
answers.explanation_why: Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame. However, telling a patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly places all responsibility for follow-up on the patient. The referring physician is responsible for obtaining the results of the tests ordered and communicating them with the patient in a timely manner.

shortness of breath, rhinorrhea, and coughing for 30 minutes 

tearing and pain in both eyes
sudden onset of symptoms at work after the release of a pungent, colorless gas when a transfer hose suddenly disconnected
was using fertilizer in a cornfield when the incident occurred; no personal protective equipment worn
